fermentables.name: Pilsen (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Light in colour and low in protein. Pilsen MD is made from the finest European two-row barley. This malt is well modified and can easily be mashed with a single temperature infusion. Due to the high enzymatic power it can be used up to 100% of the grain bill in all types of beer.

fermentables.name: Pale Ale (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Pale Ale malt is fully modified, kilned longer and more intensively. This malt gives your beer a golden colour.

fermentables.name: Munich (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Munich malt has a pronounced malty flavor, aroma and an orange-amber colour. It improves the character and full bodiness of the beer.

fermentables.name: Cara 20 (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Cara 20 MD is a very light crystal/caramel malt. The malt is produced in the drum. Due to the caramelisation and low drying temperatures its specific taste is achieved. Adding this type of malt increases the foam stability of your beers. Because of its light colour it can even be added in low percentages in your Pilsen beer to improve the foamstability.

fermentables.name: Aromatic Malt (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: The intensive germination and a mildly kilning will add a very strong malt aroma and a deep reddish colour. Amber malt clearly improves flavor stability.  The malt is rather low in diastatic power therefore it can only be used up to 30%.

fermentables.name: Biscuit (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: This toasted malt will provide a "warm bread" or biscuit flavour and aroma and will lend a garnet-brown colour. Biscuit MD is also produced in a roasting drum and has no enzymes, so it must be mashed with malts having high diastatic power.

fermentables.name: Cara 50 (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Cara 50 MD is a very light crystal/caramel malt used by a lot of Belgian breweries in producing Abbey beers. The malt is produced in the drum. Due to the  caramelisation and low drying temperatures its specific taste is achieved.

fermentables.name: Cara 120 (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Cara 120 MD is a darker caramel malt used by a lot of Belgian breweries in producing Abbey beers. The malt is produced in the drum. The malt will impart a rich caramel-sweet arome and full flavor, as well as intense dark color.

fermentables.name: Special B (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Special B MD's unique aroma and flavour is achieved through a unique double drying process. Special B MD imparts a heavy caramel taste and is often credited with the raisin-like flavor found in some Belgian Abbey beers. It can be used to substitute Chocolate or black malt when bitterness is not desired.

fermentables.name: Chocolate (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Mroost 900 MD is roasted at high temperatures and afterwards rapidly cooled when the desired color is achieved. Mroost 900 MD gives the beer a darker aroma and beer colour. Due to the unique production methods these roasted malts are less astringent.

fermentables.name: De-Bittered Black Malt (Dingemans)
fermentables.notes: Mroost 1400 MD is roasted at high temperature and afterwards rapidly cooled when the desired color is achieved. Mroost 1400 MD malt gives the beer a darker aroma and beer color, while also contributing a smoked/burnt flavour to dark beers. Due to the unique production methods these roasted malts are less astringent.

hops.name: Citra
hops.notes:
Houblons aromatiques spéciaux créés en 2007.  fort en acides alphas et huile mais peu de cohumulone.
Arôme : apporte d'intéressantes notes d'agrumes et de fruits exotiques à la bière.  
Remplaçants : inconnus

hops.name: Cascade
hops.notes:
Un houblon héritier du Northern Brewers.
Utilisation : Ales Americaines et lagers
Arôme : fortement épicé, floral et raisin
Remplaçants : Centennial
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale

hops.name: Columbus (Tomahawk)
hops.notes:
Créé spécialement pour remplacer le Centennial - houblon au fort taux d'acides alpha.
Utilisation : amérisant, saveur, arôme - IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager
Arôme : âcre, épicé. Fortement aromatique avec une saveur amère très "propre"
Remplaçants : Centennial

hops.name: Pacific Gem
hops.notes:
Croisement de smoothcone à fort taux d'alpha créé par le DSIR en 1987.
Utilisation : amérisant - avec des saveurs boisées de futs de chênes.
Arôme : agréable, des arômes de mûres.
Remplaçants : Bullion

hops.name: Perle
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant à large spectre pour les ales allemandes et américaines, aussi bien que pour les lagers
Arôme : légèrement épicé, arôme agréable, mentholé
Remplaçants : Chinook, Galena, Northern Brewer
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Pale Bock

hops.name: Styrian Goldings
hops.notes:
Variété sans graines de Fuggles cultivée en Slovénie
Utilisation : amérisant, aromatique aussi pour une grande variété de bières européennes. Très populaire donc en Europe ET au Royaume Uni
Arôme : doux, herbeux, floral. Similaire au Fuggles.
Remplaçants : Fuggles, Williamette

hops.name: Mt. Hood
hops.notes:
Utilisation : lagers européennes en aromatique
Arôme : doux avec un arôme propre et une saveur assez neutre, légèrement âcre.
Remplaçants : Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

hops.name: Saaz
hops.notes:
Utilisation : Pilsners et Bohemian lagers
Arôme : Delicat, doux, quelque peu floral -- Houblons noble
Remplaçants : Tettnanger, Lublin
Exemples : Pilsner Urquell

hops.name: Tettnang
hops.notes:
Utilisation : ales allemandes, lagers et bières de froment
Arôme : Noble, doux, fin, légèrement épicé
Remplaçants : Saaz, Spalt
Exemples : Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

hops.name: Admiral
hops.notes:
Houblon amérisant dérivé du Wye Challenger.  Haute teneur en acides alpha.
Utilisation : Ales
Arôme : Principalement amérisant
Remplaçants : Target, Northdown, Challenger

hops.name: Ahtanum
hops.notes:
Houblon clairement aromatique et modérément amérisant, originaire de Washington.
Utilisation : American ales et lagers
Arôme : floral et agrumes
Remplaçants : Amarillo, Cascade

hops.name: Amarillo Gold
hops.notes:
Origine inconnue, mais caractéristiques proche du Cascade. Utilisé tant en amérisant qu'aromatique.
Utilisation : IPAs, Ales
Arôme : Floral, agrumes
Remplaçants : Cascade, Centennial

hops.name: Apollo
hops.notes:
Variété puissante en acides alpha, issue du programme de culture Hosteiner réalisé en 2006. Ses taux élevé d'acides alpha et faible de cohumulone en font un excellent amérisant.  
Ajoute un puissant arôme de raisin/houblon en fin d'ébullition.  
Remplaçants : Nugget, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

hops.name: Aquila
hops.notes:
Houblon aromatique créé en 1988.  Usage limité du fait de son taux élevé en cohumulone.
Utilisation : Aromatique
Remplaçants : Cluster
N'est plus cultivé commercialement.

hops.name: Aramis
hops.notes:
Very fine spice and herbal notes with subtle citrus characteristics. Closely resembling Strisselspalt, but with higher oil and alpha content.

Used for: Belgian-style Ales
Substitutions: Willamette, Challenger, Ahtanum
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Atlas
hops.notes:
Croisement entre Brewers Gold et houblons sauvages de Slovénie. Principalement amérisant avec une amertume et arôme agréables.  
Utilisation : amérisant pour ales et lagers  
Remplaçants : Brewers Gold

hops.name: Aurora
hops.notes:
Aussi appelé Super Styrian. Il s'agit d'un hybride entre Norther Brewer et semences de TG (?) d'origine inconnue. Arôme houblonné agréable similaire au Styrian Goldings mais plus léger. 
Utilisation : Souvent mélangé à d'autres houblons dans les lagers.  
Remplaçants : Styrian Goldings

hops.name: Azacca
hops.notes:
Notes: Dual purpose hop. Good for dry hopping
Aroma: Citrus, tropical, floral

hops.name: Banner
hops.notes:
Houblons amérisants créés en 1988.  Utiliser largement et en continu du fait d'une conservation limitée.
Utilisation : Ales U.S.
Remplaçants : Cluster

hops.name: Bitter Gold
hops.notes:
Intense stone fruit especially pear and watermellon. A super-alpha variety with excellent aroma.

Used for: All Styles
Substitutions: Galena, Nugget

hops.name: Bobek
hops.notes:
Aussi appelé Styrian Golding B - hybride entre Northern Brewer et semences de TG. Arômes et saveurs agréables...  
Utilisation : Ales douces anglaises et lagers/Pilsners.
Remplaçants : Northern Brewer

hops.name: Bramling Cross
hops.notes:
Créé en 1927 à partir du Goldings et de variétés de houblons sauvages.
Utilisation : ESB, Bitters, Pale Ale
Arôme : doux, fruité, groseilles
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings, Progress, Whitbred

hops.name: Bravo
hops.notes:
Seconde génération de houblons à fort taux alpha créé lors du programme de reproduction Hopsteiner de 2006. Bon houblon amérisant.
Arôme : fruité et floral.
Remplaçants : Columbus, Zeus, Tomahawk

hops.name: Brewer's Gold
hops.notes:
Houblon classique amérisant pour les ales anglaises et lagers fortes allemandes.
Arôme : franche amertume
Remplaçants : Northern Brewer, Galena, Chinook, Eroica
Exemples : Pete's Wicked Ale

hops.name: Brewer's Gold, Germany
hops.notes:
Black currant, fruit and spice characteristics. Has a high resin content and gives a well-balanced bitterness which is ideally complimented by late hop additions in lager beers.

Usage: Ale, Bière de Garde, Lambic, Lager, Saison
Substitutions: Galena, Northdown, Northern Brewer
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Brewer's Gold, UK
hops.notes:
Brewers Gold is a complex bittering hop that is noted to have a sharp or pungent bittering quality. It also imparts a fruity yet spicy aroma as well as having a black currant characteristic. It is on the low end of the bittering hop scale at 8 to 10% AAU typically. Brewers Gold can be used in a wide range of styles from English Ales to German Lagers and adds a decidely 'European' element to the beer. These make a good partner to noble varieties such as Tettnang and Hallertauer.

Used for: English Ale, German Lagers
Substitutions: Bullion, Chinook, Galena

hops.name: Brooklyn
hops.notes:
A high alpha hop with distinctive tropical, grapefruit and passion fruit characters. Developed from Southern Cross.

Used for: IPAs
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Bullion
hops.notes:
Utilisé dans les ales anglaises fortes et quelques lagers fortes allemandes.
Arôme : puissant, piquant et amer.
Remplaçants : Chinook, Eroica, Brewer's Gold

hops.name: Cascade, New Zealand
hops.notes:
Flowers, citrus & spice with grapefruit the noticeable fragrance quite often. This medium aroma balances the low bittering value. Very popular hop among craft brewers.

Used for: Pale Ales, IPAs, Porters
Substitutions: Centennial, Amarillo

hops.name: Cashmere
hops.notes:
Daughter of Cascade. Mild herbal aroma with strong melon, lemon, and slightly spicy notes.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPA
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Celeia
hops.notes:
Houblon à double usage, hybride entre Savinjski Golding, Aurora et houblons sauvages de Slovénie. Proche des arômes du Saaz.  
Utilisation : lagers légères, Pilsners, et ales belges.
Remplaçants : Saaz, Styrian Goldings

hops.name: Centennial
hops.notes:
Utilisation : généralement en amérisant, aromatique dans les ales américains et bières de blé
Arôme : floral, agrumes, épicé, amertume "propre" et franche
Remplaçants : Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

hops.name: Challenger
hops.notes:
Un autre héritier du Northern Brewers
Utilisation : aromatique et amérisant pour ales et lagers
Arôme : fruité au goût, épicé en arôme, bien équilibré
Remplaçants : N/A ?

hops.name: Chelan
hops.notes:
Variété au taux d'alpha élevé issue du programme de reproduction de Haas en 2004. Déclinaison du Galena, très proche de ce dernier.
Arôme : agréables notes de citron 
Remplaçants : Galena

hops.name: Chinook
hops.notes:
Houblon fortement amérisant et polyvalent
Utilisation : Ales, porters, stouts
Arôme : puissant et épicé
Remplaçants : Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

hops.name: Chinook, New Zealand
hops.notes:
Piney with exotic spice and infused with grapefruit. This alluring aroma and a high bittering value has gained this hop full respect from craft & major brewers.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout
Substitutions: Southern Cross, Sticklebract, Nugget, Northern Brewer

hops.name: Cluster
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant la plupart du temps
Arôme : floral, légèrement épicé. Arôme et saveur bien francs
Remplaçants : Eroica, Galena

hops.name: Columbia
hops.notes:
Cousin des houblons Williamette.
Utilisation : toutes les ales anglaises
Arôme : proche du Fuggles
Remplaçants : Fuggles, Williamette

hops.name: Comet
hops.notes:
Houblon fortement amer - à utiliser avec parcimonique et d'autres houblons ;-)
Utilisation : amérisant uniquement
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Crystal
hops.notes:
Utilisation : arômes et affinage des lagers
Arôme : clair, doux, agréable et légèrement épicé
Remplaçants : Hallertauer, Mount Liberty

hops.name: Dr. Rudi
hops.notes:
A dual purpose / bittering hop with classic resinous pine and lifted citrus characters.

Used for: Ales
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Equinox (HBC 366)
hops.notes:
A pronounced aroma profile with citrus, tropical fruit, floral and herbal characteristics. Specific descriptors include lemon, lime, papaya, apple, and green pepper.

Used for: Experimental Ale
Aroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine 
Substitutions: Unknown
Storage: Unknown
14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

hops.name: Eroica
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant à large spectre pour ales, porters, stouts
Arôme : houblon clairement amérisant
Remplaçants : Galena, Northern Brewer, Chinook
Exemples : Blackhook Porter, Ballard Bitter

hops.name: Eureka!
hops.notes:
Notes: Offspring of Apollo and Merkur. Similar to Simcoe. Dual purpose. Good for dry hoping.

Aroma: Herbal, pine, mint, grapefruit rind, tangerine

hops.name: Feux Coeur Francais
hops.notes: Houblon rare au fort taux d'alpha, en provenance d'Australie (!) mais avec des ancêtres dans la région de Bourgogne. (où se déroule tous les ans une fantastique réunion internationale de brasseurs amateurs). Adaptée dans la région de Victoria et introduite en 2010.

hops.name: First Gold
hops.notes:
Houblon nain aux caractéristiques de Golding anglais
Utilisation : Ales, ESB
Arôme : similaires aux autres variétés de Goldings, épicé
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings, Crystal

hops.name: Fuggle, New Zealand
hops.notes:
Fuggle is the classic English aroma hop and is often used in conjunction with Goldings. It can be used as a main boiling hop to impart a mild, soft grassy/woody floral aroma and is also used for dry hopping.

Used for: English Ales, Porter, Stout, English IPA
Substitutions: UK Fuggle, NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding

hops.name: Fuggle, U.S.
hops.notes:
This classic English aroma variety has long been grown in both Oregon and Washington. It has a typical English aroma and contributes a balanced bitterness. Fuggle is very suitable for English and American-style Ales. Mild wood and fruit characteristics.

Used for: English Ales
Substitutions: Willamette, UK Fuggle, Styrian Golding

hops.name: Fuggles
hops.notes:
Utilisation : largement utilisé comme amérisant et aromatique pour les ales anglaises et Lagers brunes
Arôme : doux, herbeux et floral
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Exemples : Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

hops.name: Galaxy
hops.notes:
Un houblon à fort taux d'alpha, à double usage, sans graines et avec un arôme unique. Utilisé soit en amérisant soit en fin d'ébullition pour apporter des notes d'agrumes et fruit de la passion à la bière.
Arôme : Intense, agréable, unique.

hops.name: Galena
hops.notes:
Utilisation : houblon amérisant pour toutes bières
Arôme : fort, propre et amertume bien équilibrée
Remplaçants : Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook
Exemples : Catamount Porter

hops.name: Gesho Kitel
hops.notes: Brundo's aroma hops Gesho stems, gathered from the highlands of Ethiopia, are sun-dried and packed fresh. These aromatic sticks and stem flavor centuries old traditional brewing recipes for beer and Ethiopian honey wine. Acid content unknown.

hops.name: Glacier
hops.notes:
Mélange génétique d'au moins 8 varités de houblons dont : Elsasser, Brewers Gold, N Brewer, Bullion, Early Green, et autres... créé en 2000.
Utilisation : Aromatique
Arôme : Excellent , "houblonné"...............
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Golding, New Zealand
hops.notes:
Mild, delicate sweet floral character

Used for: English Ales
Substitutions: NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding, NZ Fuggle, UK East Kent Golding

hops.name: Golding, U.S.
hops.notes:
Mild and delicate with sweet floral characteristics. Bred in the US from east Kent Golding. Golding hops consist of a group of traditional English aroma varieties which have been cultivated since 1790. Several
selections now exist including Cobbs, Early Bird, East Well, Bramling, Canterbury and Mathon, some of which are now being grown in the U. S. All Goldings are recognized as having a most typical English aroma.

Used for: Bitter
Substitutions: Fuggle, Willamette, UK East Kent Golding, Styrian Golding

hops.name: Goldings, B.C.
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant et finition des ales anglaises, bitters, porters et stouts.
Arôme : épicé, floral, arôme doux et rond.
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings, Fuggles

hops.name: Goldings, East Kent
hops.notes:
Utilisation : houblon à large spectre en amérisant et aromatique des ales anglaises
Arôme : floral, aromatique, terreux, avec des saveurs légèrement épicées
Remplaçants : Fuggles, BC Goldings
Exemples : Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

hops.name: Green Bullet
hops.notes:
Houblons amérisant de Nouvelle Zélande créé en 1972
Utilisation : ales australiennes et lagers.
Arôme : floral, raisin.
Remplaçants : Styrian Goldings

hops.name: Greenburg
hops.notes: Variété de houblon nord américaine du sud de l'Idaho. Saveur fruitée et légèrement boisée. Très populaire auprès des microbrasseries.

hops.name: Hallertau Blanc
hops.notes:
Floral and fruity with passion fruit, grapefruit, pineapple, grape and lemongrass overtones. One of several new German varieties with bold flavor profiles, perfect for American-style Ales.

Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: N/A
Storage Unknown

hops.name: Hallertauer
hops.notes:
Utilisation : ales germanhic, lagers allemndes/US/Canadiennes, bières de froment
Arôme : agréable, saveurs doucement épicées, assez neutres
Remplaçants : Crystal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

hops.name: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
hops.notes:
Utilisation : lagers de style germanique et bières de froment
Arôme : noble, agréable et clair.
Remplaçants : Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh
Exemples : Wheathook Wheaten Ale

hops.name: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
hops.notes:
Utilisation : lagers continentales, germaniques et américaniques
Arôme : agréable, moyennement herbeux
Remplaçants : Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal
Exemples : Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

hops.name: Hallertauer, Nouvelle Zélande
hops.notes:
Variante d'Hallertauer aux arômes classiques avec en plus la capacité à conserver une saveur claire. Cultivée à partir de Hallertauer Mittelfrueh teuton.
Utilisation : Ales australiennes
Remplaçants : Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

hops.name: Herald
hops.notes:
Dwarf variety bred at Wye College (mid 1990s)
Utilisation : Bittering of ales
Arôme : Strong, acceptable
Remplaçants : High alpha English bittering hops

hops.name: Horizon
hops.notes:
Un bon exemple de houblon à double usage créé à partir des variétés de Nugget en Oregon (1970)
Utilisation : tous usages pour ales et lagers
Arôme : agréable et houblonné (!!)
Remplaçants : Magnum ou autres variétés à fort taux d'alpha

hops.name: Huell Melon
hops.notes:
Distinct fruit characteristics including honeydew melon and strawberry flavors. An excellent consideration for varieties not necessarily associated with typical hop flavors.

Substitutions: N/A
Storage Unkonwn

hops.name: Idaho #7
hops.notes:
Notes: Dual purpose, high alpha acid

Aroma: Tropical fruit, orange, apricot, pine.

hops.name: Jarrylo
hops.notes:
Notes: Underwhelming hop. Good if used in combination of hops with stronger flavors like Amarillo.

Aroma: Banana, pear, spice.

hops.name: Kohatu
hops.notes:
Moderate aroma with lime and pineapple with traces of pine. Overuse can exhibit "dank" character.

Used for: Belgian Ales, Wheat Beer, Blonde Ale
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Lemondrop
hops.notes:
Notes: Good for citrusy IPA, APA, IPL, or Saisons. Should be used with a hop with more distinct flavor that would benefit from the lemon flavor.

Aroma: Lemony, floral, earthy, herbal, grassy, pine, pepper

hops.name: Liberty
hops.notes:
Utilisation : lagers de style germaniques
Arôme : fin, doux, légèrement épicé
Remplaçants : Hallertau, Mt Hood, Crystal
Exemples : Pete's Wicked Lager

hops.name: Liberty, New Zealand
hops.notes: Mild and spicy, subtle lemon and citrus. Used in many styles. Contributes good bitterness in the beginning of the boil and an aroma of grapes, peaches, and vanilla at the end of the boil. Derived from Hallertau Mittlefruh.

hops.name: Lublin
hops.notes:
Version polonaise du Saaz - aussi appelée "Lubelski"
Utilisation : Bohemian lagers et Pilsners
Arôme : noble, saveur douce proche du Saaz
Remplaçants : Saaz, Tettnanger

hops.name: Magnum
hops.notes:
Hybride d'Hallertauer allemand, largement utilisé en... Allemagne !
Utilisation : ales allemandes et lagers
Arôme : bon arôme et saveur épicée
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Marynka
hops.notes:
Houblons amérisant avec un arôme puissant. Surtout utilisé pour les Pilsner, lagers, ales ou bières de froment.  Comparable aux Goldings anglais et Chinook.  
Utilisation : Lager, ales
Remplaçants : Chinook, English Golding

hops.name: Millenium
hops.notes:
Créé à l'origine pendant le programme de reproduction "Haas" aux US, sa production a démarré en 2000.  Variété à très fort taux d'alpha, utilisé comme amérisant.
Arôme : doux, herbeux
Remplaçants : Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus et Nugget

hops.name: Motueka
hops.notes:
Flexible hop developed from Saaz.  Has noble character and aroma, lemon and lime tones, balanced bitterness, and unique flavor.

Used for: Lagers, Belgian Ales and Bohemian Pilsner.  
Substitutions: Saaz, Sterling

hops.name: Nelson Sauvin
hops.notes:
Variété triploïde cultivée à partir de "Smoothcone" et commercialisée à partir de 2000.  On rapporte des parfums de groseilles fraichement écrasées similaires au Sauvignon blanc qui lui donnerait son nom... (!)  Très fruité, agrumes - à utiliser avec mode et ration.  
Utilisation : Pale ale, Super Premiums.  
Remplaçants : aucun ! Non mais...

hops.name: Newport
hops.notes:
Houblon à fort taux d'alpha, créé en 2002, peut être avantageusement utilisé en remplacement du Galena. A noter que ces houblons ont un taux d'alpha variable entre 9.8% et 17%, alors vérifiez bien son emballage ! Peut paraitre légèrement âcre également.
Utilisation : surtout utilisé en amérisant des ales, stouts, barley wine.  
Remplaçants : Galena

hops.name: Northdown
hops.notes:
Variation sur le thèmme du Northern Brewers cultivée en Angleterre.
Utilisation : amérisant pour les ales anglaises
Arôme : bonne amertume, saveur et arôme (avec ça on est bien avancés)
Remplaçants : Northern Brewer

hops.name: Northern Brewer
hops.notes:
Aussi appelé Hallertauer Northern Brewers
Utilisation : amérisant et aromatique aussi bien pour les ales que les lagers de tous genres (et même certaines limonades)
Arôme : fin, sec, houblon clairement amer à la saveur unique.
Remplaçants : Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer
Exemples : Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

hops.name: Nugget
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant pour les ales
Arôme : fortement amer, lourd, arôme herbeux, épicé
Remplaçants : Chinook
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Porter

hops.name: Olympic
hops.notes:
Le houblon Olympic au fort taux d'alpha a été créé par le Washington Agricultural Expt Station en 1983. Il puise ses origines dans les Brewers Gold et Fuggles.
Arôme : épicé, agrumes
Remplaçants : Brewers Gold

hops.name: Opal
hops.notes:
Variété nouvelle en provenance du centre de recherche sur les houblons de Hull.
Utilisation : aromatique pour les styles continentaux
Arôme : puissants avec des pointes épicées et d'agrumes.
Remplaçants : inconnus

hops.name: Orion
hops.notes:
Croisement entre Perle et variétés expérimentales
Utilisation : amérisant et aromatique
Arôme : agréable, houblonné (!)
Remplaçants : Perle

hops.name: Pacific Jade
hops.notes:
Houblon amérisant à fort taux d'alpha révélant des arômes herbeux et agrumes avec des saveurs de poivre noir. L'arôme et saveur de citron adoucit les ales et peut être alors utilisé comme aromatique. 
Utilisation : Ales, lagers 
Remplaçants : aucun

hops.name: Pacifica
hops.notes:
Houblon aromatique créé à partir du Hallertauer Mittelfrueh en Nouvelle Zélande (1994).  Mélange de goûts de l'ancien et du nouveau monde : marmelade d'orange et aromes d'agrumes lors d'utilisation en fin d'ébullition. Des arômes plus doux en cas d'utilisation comme amérisant. 
Remplaçants : Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

hops.name: Palisade
hops.notes:
Aussi appelé YCR-4 (quel joli nom!), le Palisade est une variété aromatique cultivé dans les ranches de Yakima Chief (yeehah !). 
Il possède des propriétés aussi bien aromatiques qu'amérisantes.  
Remplaçants : Willamette

hops.name: Pekko
hops.notes:
Notes: Any style that coud incorporate Saaz could use Pekko.

Aroma: Floral, mint, herbal, citrus

hops.name: Perle, U.S.
hops.notes:
Bred from English Northern Brewer. Slightly spicy with herbal and floral characteristics.

Used for: Stout
Substitutions: Northern Brewer, German Northern Brewer, German Perle

hops.name: Phoenix
hops.notes:
Semences dérivées du Wye Yoeman.
Utilisation : Ales
Arôme : Similaire au Wye Challenger
Remplaçants : Challenger, East Kent Golding, Northdown

hops.name: Pilgrim
hops.notes:
Nouvelle variété du Wye College crée en 2001. Taux élevé de Selinene.
Utilisation : amérisant
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Pilot
hops.notes:
Toute nouvelle variété de houblon introduite en 2002 par Charles Faram & Co Ltd. Des saveurs douces et herbeuses avec des touches de citron et d'herbe fraîchement fauchée.  
Utilisation : principalement en amérisant des APAs.  
Rare.

hops.name: Pioneer
hops.notes:
Cultivé à partir du Wye Omega au Wye College (UK)
Utilisation : ESB, English Ales
Arôme : typique des houblons aromatiques doux anglais
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings

hops.name: Premiant
hops.notes:
Croisement entre diverses variétés tchèques d'amérisants et aromatiques. Houblon à double usage même si son arôme n'est pas aussi puissant que d'autres houblons tchèques. A utiliser pour les bières nécessitant un arôme de houblon plutôt modéré.  
Utilisation : ales légèrement houblonnées, lagers 
Remplaçants : Saaz

hops.name: Pride of Ringwood
hops.notes:
Utilisation : généralement utilisé comme amérisant pour les bières australiennes
Arôme : modérément citroné avec des saveurs clairement amères
Remplaçants : Cluster, Galena

hops.name: Progress
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant et aromatique pour les ales anglaises
Arôme : similaire au Fuggles, aromatique, légèrement sucré
Remplaçants : Fuggles

hops.name: Riwaka
hops.notes:
A l'origine appelé aussi B-Saaz, il fut créé d'après une ancienne variété de houblons Saazer en Nouvelle Zélande.  
Utilisation : pale ale nord américaines, pilsners locales
Arôme : puissant, houblonné. Des touches de raisin et d'agrumes.

hops.name: Santiam
hops.notes:
Sélection aromatique triploïde dérivée des Tettnang et Hallertauer (1997)
Utilisation : Lager, U.S. Pale Ale, Pilsner
Remplaçants : German Tettnang, Spalt, Spalt Select

hops.name: Saphir
hops.notes:
Une nouvelle variété noble comme alternative au Hallertau Mittelfrueh pour tenter de le rendre plus résistants aux maladies et commercialement plus viable. Similaire en caractéristiques aux autres variétés d'Hallertau.  
Utilisation : Pilsners, lagers, blanches belges.  
Remplaçants : Hallertau Mittelfrueh

hops.name: Satus
hops.notes:
Houblons à fort taux d'alpha de Yakima similaire au Galena.  Origine récente.  
Remplaçants : Galena

hops.name: Select Spalt
hops.notes:
Cultivé d'après les variétés de Hallertauer Mittelfrueh et Spalt en Allemagne. Plus proche du Spalt en caractère.
Utilisation : Lager, Pilsner, en substitut de variété noble aromatique
Arôme : très fin, arômes de Spalt
Remplaçants : Spalter, Saaz, Tettnang

hops.name: Simcoe
hops.notes:
Houblons amérisants à fort taux d'alpha avec des très bonnes qualités aromatiques.
Utilisation : IPAs
Arôme : agrumes et pins
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Sladek
hops.notes:
Variété hybride tirée du Saaz avec des arômes et saveurs de houblons nobles. Généralement recommandée pour un houblonnage moyen à 20mn avant la fin d'ébullition. Pas forcément en remplacement du Saaz, mais complémentaire, notamment pour les lagers.  
Utilisation : Lagers
Remplaçants : Saaz

hops.name: Sonnet Golding
hops.notes:
Sonnet is a new hop variety bred from a Saaz variant that exhibited Goldings-like characteristics. It's used for aroma due to its low alpha acid content, and offers lots of floral notes.

Used for: English Ales, Belgian Style Ales
Substitutions: Saaz,East Kent Golding and Crystal.
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Sorachi Ace
hops.notes:
Créé par les brasseries Sapporo (japon) et utilisé dans leurs bières - comme héritier des variétés de Brewer's Gold et Saaz. Réputé pour présenter des saveurs et arômes de citron.  
Utilisation : Saison, IPA ou autres bières nécessitant des arômes citronnés.  
Remplaçants : Admiral, Cascade

hops.name: Southern Cross
hops.notes:
Houblon double usage avec des "saveurs européennes".................
Créé en 1994 par le DSIR
Utilisation : aromatique ou amérisant pour un authentique goût européen........
Arôme : épicé, citronné, légèrement pineux (arômes de pins !) et boisé
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Sovereign
hops.notes:
Pleasant but intense fruity flavors with mild floral, grassy, herbal and mint characteristics.

Used for: Pale Ale
Substitution: Fuggles
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Spalter
hops.notes:
Utilisation : amérisant et aromatique traditionnel des styles allemands : Altbiers, Lagers
Arôme : doux, agréable, légèrement épicé
Remplaçants : Saaz, Tettnang
Exemples : Dusseldorf Altbiers

hops.name: Sterling
hops.notes:
Au goût à mi chemin entre Saaz et Mt Hood
Utilisation : Lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Arôme : herbeux, épicé, quelque peu floral avec des notes d'agrumes
Remplaçants : Saaz, Polish Lublin

hops.name: Sticklebract
hops.notes:
Houblon à fort taux d'alpha, préalablement créé par la recherche du DSIR en 1972. Quelques qualités proches du Northern Brewer
Utilisation : aromatique et amérisant
Arôme : pins et notes d'agrumes
Remplaçants : Northern Brewer

hops.name: Strisslespalt
hops.notes:
Houblons aromatiques largement utilisés en Alsace (France).
Utilisation : Pilsner, lager, bières de froment
Arôme : intesité moyenne, agréable, houblonnée
Remplaçants : Mt Hood, Crystal, Hallertauer Hersbruck

hops.name: Summit
hops.notes:
Variété au fort taux d'alpha cultiveé par la American Dwarf Hop Assoc.  Peut être cultivée commercialement sur treillis de faible hauteur.  
Arôme : fortement agrumes, des notes de raisin.
Remplaçants : Warrior, Millenium, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

hops.name: Sun
hops.notes:
Houblons amérisants à fort taux d'alpha de la Yakima Valley, Washington
Utilisation : amérisant (intense)
Arôme : agréable, houblonné
Remplaçants : autres variétés de houblons américains à fort taux d'alpha

hops.name: Super Alpha
hops.notes:
Houblons à fort taux d'alpha créé en 1976 par le DSIR. Plutôt "européren" en caractère (ça veut tout dire) - arôme croustillant et résineux.
Utilisation : amérisant pour les styles européens
Arôme : agréable, résineux
Remplaçants : N/A

hops.name: Super Galena
hops.notes:
Houblons au taux d'alpha très élevé issu du programme de reproduction Hopsteiner en 2006. Hautes teneurs en alpha et beta - comparable au Galena en amertume et profil aromatique.  
Utilisation : principalement en amérisant.  
Remplaçants : Galena

hops.name: Super Pride
hops.notes:
Variation à fort taux d'alpha du Pride of Ringwood. 
Présente des arômes doux, un taux d'alpha plus élevé et de cohumulone plus faible.  
Utilisation : principalement en amérisant.  
Remplaçants : Pride of Ringwood

hops.name: Sussex
hops.notes:
Aroma similar to Fuggle. Good, yet delicate, flavor retention. Pedigree is "a chance find". 

Used for: Ale
Sustitution: N/A
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Tahoma
hops.notes: Citrus and lemon notes with cedar, pine, floral, pepper and subtle green melon notes. Daughter of Glacier that retains the very low cohumulone characteristic of Glacier with somewhat higher alpha acid content.

hops.name: Target
hops.notes:
Utilisation : ales anglaises et lagers
Arôme : arôme et saveur robustes
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings

hops.name: Tettnang, U.S.
hops.notes:
Tettnang is a traditional German land-race variety known for
its noble aroma that is pleasant and slightly spicy. It remains well established in the Tettnang growing region of Germany, and is also grown in Oregon and Washington. Americangrown Tettnang is reported to have slightly higher myrcene levels than its German counterpart.

Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: German Tettnang, Santiam, German Spalt, Spalt Select

hops.name: Tillicum
hops.notes:
Houblons aux forts taux d'alpha et beta créé par le programme de reproduction de Haas en 1995. Variété cousine du Galena et proche du Chelan - similaire aux deux. 
Remplaçants : Galena, Chelan

hops.name: Tomahawk
hops.notes:
Partie intégrante du trio célèbre Columbus/Tomahak/Zeus (CTZ) des houblons à super hauts taux d'alpha. A eux trois ils représentent déjà 1/4 des surfaces de cultures de houblons.  
Utilisation : houblons à fort taux d'alpha utilisé surtout en amérisant de bières commerciales.  
Remplaçants : Tomahawk, Zeus, Nugget, Galena, Chinook

hops.name: Topaz
hops.notes: Variété de houblons à taux d'alpha très important, en provenance d'Australie. Utilisé surtout en production commerciale pour ses hautes teneurs en acide alpha (on en met moins) et sa forte amertume..

hops.name: Tradition
hops.notes:
Proche descendant du Hallertauer Mittelfrueh cultivé pour son haut rendement.
Utilisation : Lager, Pilsner, Bock, certaines Weizens
Arôme : Fin - similaire au Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
Remplaçants : Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Liberty, Ultra

hops.name: Triple Pearl
hops.notes:
Pleasant and balanced with notes of melon, orange citrus, resin, spice and pepper. Stoarge stability unknown. Released in 2013 by USDA-ARS.

Used for: Pale Ale
Substitutions: Perle

hops.name: Triskel
hops.notes:
A cross between Strisselspalt and the male plant of the English hop variety of Yeoman. Contains many of the same characteristics as Strisselspalt, but with a more pronounced flavor profile. Strong floral, fruit and citrus characteristics.

Used for: Belgian style ale, Lager, IPA, Pilsner, Wheat
Substitutions: Ahtanum, Centennial, Chinook, Simcoe
Storage: Unknown

hops.name: Ultra
hops.notes:
Variété triploïde issue du Hallertauer allemand.
Utilisation : Lager, Pilsner, bières de froment, aromatique également pour les ales
Arôme : bon à remarquable - parfois proche des qualités du Saaz
Remplaçants : Liberty, Hallertauer, Tradition, Saaz

hops.name: Vanguard
hops.notes:
Variété diploïde crée en 1982, commercialisée en 1997. Des parentés avec le Hallertau Mitterfrueh.
Utilisation : lagers européennes, ales
Arôme : de puissantes notes aromatiques (oui mais lesquelles ?)
Remplaçants : Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

hops.name: Victoria
hops.notes:
Houblons à fort taux d'alpha cultivé dans la région de Victoria, en Australie. Crée en 1976 entrée en production commerciale dans les années 1990.
Utilisation : principalement en amérisant du fait de son taux d'alpha important.

hops.name: Wai-iti
hops.notes:
Strong citrus character of lime zest with fresh peaches and apricot. Used in both ales and lagers. Good for late additions and dry hopping.

Used for: Ale, Pale Ale, IPA.
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Waimea
hops.notes:
A high alpha acid, dual purpose hop with lots of pine and citrus characters. 

Used for: IPA
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Warrior
hops.notes:
Houblon à fort taux d'alpha des ranches de Yakima Chiefs. Aussi appelé YCR-5.  Arômes doux et faible teneur en cohumulone - principalement amérisant.
Utilisation : Ales, stouts
Arôme : neutre, propre et doux
Remplaçants : Nugget, Columbus, Magnum

hops.name: Whitbread Golding Variety (WGV)
hops.notes:
Dérivé anglophile du Bates Brewer en 1911. Des caractéristiques proches des Goldings mais trop faible pour rejoindre les qualités aromatiques de ces derniers.
Utilisation : Ales
Arôme : agréable, houblonné, assez intense
Remplaçants : East Kent Goldings, Progress

hops.name: Willamette
hops.notes:
Utilisation : aromatique pour les ales britanniques et américaines
Arôme : doux, herbeux, floral, légèrement épicé
Remplaçants : Fuggles, East Kent Goldings
Exemples : Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

hops.name: Willamette, New Zealand
hops.notes:
Mild, pleasant, slight spicy floral tones.

Used for: American and English Ales
Substitutions: US Willamette, Fuggles

hops.name: Wye Challenger
hops.notes:
Spicy, clean, citrus aroma with distinct herbal notes.

Used for: English Ales, English IPA, Red Ale, Bitter, Stout, Porter
Substitutions: N/A

hops.name: Yakima Gold
hops.notes: Aroma is mild and pleasant. An excellent general purpose variety with smooth bitterness and a pleasant aroma. Released by Washington State University in 2013.

hops.name: Zeus
hops.notes:
Houblons à très fort taux d'alpha créé dans la Yakima Valley, état de Washington
Utilisation : amérisant à l'arôme intense (!)
Arôme : Aromatique, agréable
Remplaçants : autres houblons à fort taux d'alpha

yeasts.name: Abbaye Belgian
yeasts.notes:
Complex aroma and flavors may include peppery, fruity, banana,
clovy, alcoholic, sweet and fruity. Does not display undesirable odors
when properly handled.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales

yeasts.name: Abbey Ale
yeasts.notes: Used in two of six remaining Trappist breweries.  Distinctive plum and fruitiness.  Good for high gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Trappist Ale, Spiced Ale, Trippel, Dubbel, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: Abbey Ale C
yeasts.notes: From a famous Trappist brewery, this yeast produces the distinctive fruitiness and plum characteristics. Excellent yeast for high gravity beers, Belgian ales, dubbels and trippels.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Abbey Ales, Trappist Ales

yeasts.name: Abbey IV Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: An authentic Trappist style ale yeast.  Use for Belgian ales including abbey ales (dubbels, tripels).  Fruit character is medium - between WLP500 (high) and WLP530 (low)
yeasts.bestFor: Trappist Belgian Ales, Dubbels, Tripels and Specialty ales

yeasts.name: Achouffe Belgian
yeasts.notes: Abbey style yeast from the Belgian Ardennes. Produces aromatic, spicy clove-like notes and less fruity aromas than GY014. Moderately flocculant yeast that creates a slightly clearer beer than most Belgians.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: All The Bretts
yeasts.notes: This will be an evolving blend comprised of nearly every Brettanomyces strain in our collection (inaugural release will contain 12 strains).  When used in secondary, expect high attenuation and a fruity and funky complexity developing over time.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales

yeasts.name: Alt
yeasts.notes: Top cropping yeast from Germany with clean flavor profile and broad fermentation range. Beers mature rapidly, even when cold fermentation is used. Low or no detectable diacetyl. Compares to WLP036 and WY1007.
yeasts.bestFor: Alt biers, Dusseldorf Alts, German Ales.

yeasts.name: Altstadt Ale
yeasts.notes: An ale yeast that ferments at cold temperatures and produces a lager like ale style with a hint of fruity esters.  Leaves a slight residual maltiness perfect for traditional Kölsch and Alt styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, California Common, Altbier, Biere de Garde, Cream Ale

yeasts.name: American Ale
yeasts.notes: Soft, smooth, clean finish.  Very well balanced.  Very versitile -- works well with many ale styles.
yeasts.bestFor: American Pale Ale, Scottish Ale, Porters, Sweet Stout, Barley Wine, Alt

yeasts.name: American Ale II
yeasts.notes: Clean, tart, nutty flavor.  More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine

yeasts.name: American Ale Yeast Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend that celebrates WLP001 (California Ale Yeast's) clean, neutral fermentation.  This strain is versatile and adds two other yeast strains that are also clean/neutral in flavor to add a bit of complexity - almost a lager like finish.  Slight sulfur m
yeasts.bestFor: American ales with clean finish

yeasts.name: American Farmhouse Blend
yeasts.notes: Inspired by local American brewers crafting semi-  traditional Belgian-style ales. This blend creates a complex flavor profile with a moderate level of sourness. It consists of a traditional farmhouse yeast strain and Brettanomyces. Great yeast for farmho
yeasts.bestFor: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales

yeasts.name: American Hefeweizen Ale
yeasts.notes: Produces a much smaller amount of clove and banana flavor than the German Hefeweizen White Labs yeast.  Some sulfur, and creates desired cloudy look.
yeasts.bestFor: Oregon style American Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: American Lager
yeasts.notes: This yeast is a powerful attenuator that creates a dry lager with a slightly fruity finish and very little sulfide and diacetyl.  Perfect for lager styles where you desire a dry, less malty finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Lager, Black Lager, Pilsner, Schwarzbier, Imperial Pilsner

yeasts.name: American Lager
yeasts.notes: Complex and aromatic strain that can be used for a variety of lager beers. Excellent choice for Classic American Pilsner beers.
yeasts.bestFor: American Lagers and Pilsners

yeasts.name: American Lager
yeasts.notes: Bold, with a complex aroma.  Good flavor depth characteristics for a wide variety of lager beers.
yeasts.bestFor: American Lagers and Pilsners

yeasts.name: American Lager Yeast
yeasts.notes: Dry and clean with very slight apple fruitiness.  Minimal sulfer and diacetyl.
yeasts.bestFor: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.

yeasts.name: American Megabrewery
yeasts.notes: Smooth yeast with a slight fruity flavor.  Lagers into a smooth, clean tasting beer.  Use for light, clean lager styles with unobtrusive yeast character.
yeasts.bestFor: Light, Clean American style lagers.

yeasts.name: American Microbrewery Ale #1
yeasts.notes: Smooth, clean, strong fermenting ale yeast that works well at cold temperature.  Clean malt flavor is ideal for cream ales.
yeasts.bestFor: American Ales, Cream Ales

yeasts.name: American Microbrewery Ale #2
yeasts.notes: Accentuated, rich, creamy malt profile.  Generous amounts of diacytl.  Use for low gravity beers where malt character is needed or stronger beers for a robust character.
yeasts.bestFor: American ales

yeasts.name: American Microbrewery Lager
yeasts.notes: Strong fermenter. Leaves a clean, full flavored, malty finish.  Slightly attenuative.  Versatile for most lager styles with a clean full flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: All lager styles

yeasts.name: American Pilsner
yeasts.notes: A mild, neutral strain that produces beers with a nice malty character and a smooth palate. Dry and clean with a very slight apple fruitiness. Sulfur and diacetyl production is minimal. Beers from this strain exhibit the characteristics of the most popular lager in America.
yeasts.bestFor: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.

yeasts.name: American West Coast Ale
yeasts.notes:
BRY-97 is suitable for primary fermentation for beers up to 12% ABV. The yeast
would require extra nutrition above that level of alcohol such as an addition of
1g/hL of Servomyces. Slightly estery, almost neutral.
yeasts.bestFor:
American Barleywine, American Pale Ale, American Amber ale, American Brown
ale, American IPA, American Wheat, blonde ale, Cream ale, Kölsch, Imperial IPA,
Irish red ale, Extra Special bitter, Scottish ale, Strong Scottish ale, Strong ale

yeasts.name: American Wheat
yeasts.notes: True top cropping yeast that produces a dry, slightly tart, crisp beer. Low ester profile.
yeasts.bestFor: American Wheat, Berlin Weiss, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: American White Ale
yeasts.notes: Smooth wheat yeast with a round, clean, malt flavor.  Low flocculation leaves cloudy Hefe-Weizen finish.  Smooth flavor makes a great unfiltered wheat beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Hefe-Weizen, American Wheat

yeasts.name: American Wheat Ale
yeasts.notes: Dry, Crisp, tart beer in the American Hefeweizen style.  Low flocculation aids in producing desired chill haze.
yeasts.bestFor: American Wheat, Berlin Weiss, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Antwerp Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Clean, almost lager like Belgian ale yeast.  Good for Belgian pale and amber ales or with other Belgian yeasts in a blend.  Biscuity, ale like aroma present.  Hop flavors are accentuated.  Slight sulfur during fermentation, and a lager like flavor profile
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian pale and amber ales

yeasts.name: Assmanshausen Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: German red wine yeast, which results in spicy, fruit aromas. Perfect for Pinot Noir and Zinfandel. Slow to moderate fermenter which is cold tolerant.  Alcohol Tolerance: 16%
yeasts.bestFor: Pinot Noir and Zinfandel

yeasts.name: Augustiner Lager
yeasts.notes: Versatile yeast that produces low sulfur and diacetyl.
yeasts.bestFor: Vienna Lagers, Helles

yeasts.name: Australian Ale
yeasts.notes: Produces a malty, bready, nutty character with a pleasant honey like finish. This yeast emphasizes malt nuances and is very forgiving in warmer fermentations for those who cannot ferment under controlled conditions.
yeasts.bestFor: Australian styles

yeasts.name: Australian Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: White Labs entry for Australian Ales.  Produces a clean, malty finish with pleasant ester character.  Bready character.  Can ferment clean at high temperatures.
yeasts.bestFor: Australian Ales, English Ales

yeasts.name: Avize Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: Champagne isolate used for complexity in whites. Contributes elegance, especially in barrel fermented Chardonnays.  Alcohol tolerance to 15%.
yeasts.bestFor: Chardonnay

yeasts.name: Bastogne Belgian Ale
yeasts.notes: High gravity Trappist ale yeast.  Creates a dry beer with a slightly acidic finish.  Cleaner finish and slightly less spicy than WLP500 or WLP530.
yeasts.bestFor: High gravity beers, Belgian ales, Dubbels, Trippels.

yeasts.name: Bavarian Hefe
yeasts.notes: A traditional hefe yeast from one of Bavaria’s oldest breweries.  Robust attenuator that works over a broad range of temperatures and produces the classic banana and clove notes of the German wheat beer style.  Moderate sulfide producer (will dissipate with conditioning).
yeasts.bestFor: Dunkelweizen, Gose, Hefeweizen, Weizenbock

yeasts.name: Bavarian Lager
yeasts.notes: A bottom fermenting yeast suitable for most lager styles. Promotes less sulphur production than other lager strains as well as a fuller, more rounded malt character with well-promoted hop flavours.
yeasts.bestFor: Lagers, Pilsners, Helles, Munich Dunkel, Rauchbier.

yeasts.name: Bavarian Lager
yeasts.notes: Use by many German breweries.  Produces a full-bodied, rich, malty beer.
yeasts.bestFor: German Bocks, Vienna, Oktoberfest, Hells, Marzens, Dunkel

yeasts.name: Bavarian Weizen Yeast
yeasts.notes: Former yeast lab W51 strain.  Produces a classic German style wheat beer with moderately high, spicy, phenolic overtones reminiscent of cloves.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian Weizen and wheat beers.

yeasts.name: Bavarian Wheat
yeasts.notes: Produces apple, pear, and plum esters in addition to the dominant banana character. The esters are complemented nicely by clove and subtle vanilla phenolics. The balance can be manipulated towards ester production through increasing fermentation temperature, increasing the wort density, and decreasing the pitch rate. Over pitching can result in a near complete loss of banana character. Decreasing the ester level will allow a higher clove character to be perceived. Sulfur is commonly produced, but will dissipate with conditioning. This strain is very powdery and will remain in suspension for an extended amount of time following attenuation. This is true top cropping yeast and requires fermenter headspace of 33%.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian Weizen and wheat beers.

yeasts.name: Bavarian Wheat
yeasts.notes: Hefeweizen yeast with complex flavor and aroma.  Bubble gum, banana flavors with apple/plub ester profile.  Malty flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian Weizen, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Bavarian Wheat Yeast
yeasts.notes: Blend of top-fermenting ale and wheat yeasts providing a mild ester and phenolic profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian style wheat beers.

yeasts.name: Bedford British Ale
yeasts.notes: High attenuation. Ferments dry with high flocculation. Distinctive ester profile.  Good for most English ale styles.
yeasts.bestFor: English style ales - bitter, pale, porter and brown ale

yeasts.name: Belgian Abbaye
yeasts.notes: This yeast produces classic Belgian-style ales - robust, estery with a large note of clove and fruit. Rated highly in sensory tests described in "Brew Like a Monk" for complexity and low production of higher alcohols. Attenuation 74-76%, fermentation temperature 66-72F.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian style ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Abbaye 2
yeasts.notes: Traditional Belgian yeast with a complex, dry, fruity malt profile. Rated highly in sensory tests described in "Brew Like a Monk" for complexity and low production of higher alcohols. Attenuation 74-76%; fermentation temperature: 66-72F.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian style ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Abbey
yeasts.notes: Moderately alcohol tolerant with fewer phenols than Belgian Ale, this yeast is exceptionally fruity with hugely complex esters and is highly flocculant.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Pale Ales and Abbey Ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Abbey II
yeasts.notes: Dry flavor with slight fruitiness. High alcohol tolerance.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Trappist Ales, Abbey Ales, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale
yeasts.notes: Phenolic and spicy flavors.  Complex profile, with less fruitiness than White's Trappist Ale strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Saisons, Belgian Reds, Belgian Browns, White beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale #1
yeasts.notes: Produces classic Belgian ale flavor.  Robust, estery with notes of clove and fruit. Ferments well in high gravity worts.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, High gravity ales.

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale #2
yeasts.notes: Flanders style yeast.  Strong fermenting yeast attenuates well and produces fruity, malty, estery malt profile.  Slow to flocculate.
yeasts.bestFor: Flanders style Belgian Ales, Belgian Brown, Fruit beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale #3
yeasts.notes: Slightly more refined than CL-300.  Produces the classic Trappist ale character with esters of spice and fruit. Mildly phenolic.  Strong fermenting yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian ales, Trappist Ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale A
yeasts.notes: Versatile strain for the production of classic Belgian style ales. This strain produces a beautiful balance of delicate fruit esters and subtle spicy notes, with neither one dominating. Unlike many other Belgian style strains, this strain is highly flocculent and results in bright beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Saisons, Belgian Reds, Belgian Browns, White beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale D
yeasts.notes: The best choice for brewing golden strong ales. This alcohol tolerant strain will produce a complex ester profile balanced nicely with subtle phenolics. Malt flavors and aromas will remain even with a well attenuated dry, tart finish. It may continue to produce CO2 for an extended period after packaging or collection.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Scottish Strong Ale,Trappist Ales, Dubbels, Trippels

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale DK
yeasts.notes: Clean Belgian type ale yeast.  Good for Belgian style pale ales and amber ales.  Biscuity, ale-like aroma with accentuated hop flavor and bitterness.  Slight sulfur will be produced during fermentation, which can give the yeast a lager-like flavor profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian pale and amber ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale O
yeasts.notes: A Trappist style ale yeast. Produces dry beer with slight acidic finish, but cleaner than OYL-018 and OYL-028. Good choice for high gravity beers, Belgian ales, dubbels and trippels.
yeasts.bestFor: High gravity beers, Belgian ales, Dubbels, Trippels.

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale R
yeasts.notes: Great choice for use in Belgian dark strong ales. This strain has a relatively “clean profile” which allows a rich malt and distinctive ethanol character to shine. Delicate dried fruit esters can be produced when used at higher fermentation temperatures or in a high gravity wort.
yeasts.bestFor: Trappist Belgian Ales, Dubbels, Tripels and Specialty ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale W
yeasts.notes: Classic strain for brewing Belgian dubbel or Belgian tripel. This strain produces a nice balance of complex fruity esters and phenolics, making it desirable for use in other Belgian style ales as well. A flocculent, true top cropping yeast (additional headspace is recommended), that will work over a broad temperature range. Makes a great Belgian style “house” strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Trappist Ale, Spiced Ale, Trippel, Dubbel, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: Belgian Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Trappist style ale yeast.  Complex estery flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Abbey Ales, Trappist Ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Ardennes
yeasts.notes: Phenolics develop at increased temperature.  Mild fruitiness and complex spicy flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale

yeasts.name: Belgian Dark Ale
yeasts.notes: Belgian ale yeast that is a high acid producer with balanced ester and phenol production. High alcohol tolerance. Spicy, tart, and dry on the palate with a very complex finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Strong Dark and Golden Ales, Belgian Quadrupel, Oud Bruin/Flanders Brown, Fruit Beers, Belgian Specialty Beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Golden Ale
yeasts.notes: Combination of fruitiness and phenolic characters dominate the profile.  Some sulfur which will dissapate following fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Dubbel, Grand Cru, Belgian Holiday Ale

yeasts.name: Belgian Lager Yeast
yeasts.notes: Clean, crisp European lager yeast with low sulfur  production. The strain originates from a very old brewery in West Belgium.  Great for European style pilsners, dark  lagers, Vienna lager, and American style lagers.
yeasts.bestFor: European style pilsners, dark  lagers, Vienna lager, and American style lagers

yeasts.name: Belgian Lambic Blend
yeasts.notes: Lambic culture of Saccharomyces Cerevisiar and a mixture of yeasts and bacterias.  Blend of organisms helps create lactic flavor of Belgian Lambics.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic

yeasts.name: Belgian Mix
yeasts.notes: A blend of Trappist Ale Yeast combine to create robust attenuation and a complex flavor profile.  Spicy and fruity, this blend is slightly more flocculent than many Belgians.  Good choice for High Gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde, Saison

yeasts.name: Belgian Saison
yeasts.notes: Most widely used farmhouse ale yeast. A traditional yeast that is spicy with complex aromatics, including bubble gum. It is very tart and dry on the palate with a mild fruitiness. Will yield a crisp, mildly acidic finish that will benefit from elevated fermentation temperatures. This strain is notorious for a rapid and vigorous start to fermentation, only to stick around 1.035 S.G. Fermentation will finish, given time and warm temperatures. Warm fermentation temperatures, at least 90°F (32°C), or the use of a secondary strain can accelerate attenuation.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Saison

yeasts.name: Belgian Saison
yeasts.notes: Classic farmhouse ale yeast.  Spicy, complex aromatics including bubble gum.  Tart and dry on the palate with mild fruitiness.  Finishes crisp and mildly acidic.  Ferment at warm temperature.  May have vigorous fermentation start.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Saison beer

yeasts.name: Belgian Saison I Ale
yeasts.notes: Saison yeast from Wallonia.  Earthy, spicy and peppery notes.  Slightly sweet.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison Ale, Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Trippel

yeasts.name: Belgian Saison II
yeasts.notes: This strain produces complex esters balanced with earthy/spicy notes. Slightly tart and dry with a peppery finish. A perfect strain for farmhouse ales and saisons.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Biere de Garde, Belgian Blonde Ale, Belgian Pale Ale, Belgian Golden Strong Ale

yeasts.name: Belgian Saison II Yeast
yeasts.notes: Saison strain with a more fruity ester profile than WLP565 (Belgian Saison I Yeast).  Moderately phenolic with a clove-like characteristic in finished beer flavor and aroma.  Ferments quickly.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian or French Saison

yeasts.name: Belgian Sour Mix 1
yeasts.notes: Note: Bacteria to use in secondary only.  A unique blend perfect for Belgian style beers. Includes Brettanomyces, Saccharomyces, and the bacterial strains Lactobacillus and Pediococcus.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour beers (in secondary)

yeasts.name: Belgian Strong Ale
yeasts.notes: Dry, tart, fruity flavor.  High alcohol tolerance.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Scottish Strong Ale,Trappist Ales, Dubbels, Trippels

yeasts.name: Belgian Strong Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: From the Ardennes region of Belgium, this classic strain produces moderate esters and spicy phenolic character.  Results in a dry but balanced finish.  Use for dark or strong abbey ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian dark strongs, Abbey ales and Christmas beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Style Ale Yeast Blend
yeasts.notes: Blend of two trappist ale yeasts and one Belgian ale yeast.  Creates a versatile blend to be used for Trappist and other Belgian style ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Trappist and other Belgian ales.

yeasts.name: Belgian Style Saison Ale Yeast Blend
yeasts.notes: This blend melds Belgian style ale and Saison strains. The strains work in harmony to create complex, fruity aromas and flavors. The blend of yeast strains encourages complete fermentation in a timely manner. Phenolic, spicy, earthy, and clove like flavor
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian and French Saison

yeasts.name: Belgian Tripel
yeasts.notes: Provides a fantastic complex marriage of spice, fruity esters, phenolics and alcohol. It is also very attenuative with a high alcohol tolerance making it perfect for a range of Belgian styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Tripel and Trappist style beers.

yeasts.name: Belgian Wheat
yeasts.notes: Top fermenting yeast with a soft bread-like character.  Leaves a sweet, mildly estery finish.  Delicious Belgian character to any beer.  Great in Wit style with coriander and bitter orange peel.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Pils, Belgian Wit

yeasts.name: Belgian Wheat
yeasts.notes: Produces beers with moderate esters and minimal phenolics.  Apple, bubblegum, and plum-like aromas blend nicely with malt and hops.  This strain will finish dry with a hint of tartness.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wheat, Bavarian Weizen

yeasts.name: Belgian Wheat Yeast
yeasts.notes: Estery lor phenol yeast.  Plum and apple aroma with a dry finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wheat, Bavarian Weizen

yeasts.name: Belgian Wit
yeasts.notes: Traditional Belgian Wit yeast from one of the classic producers of the style.  Creates a delicious spicy nose and a somewhat tart beer.  Attenuates dry and leaves a slightly cloudy beer— very low flocculation.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Witbier, Saison, Belgian Ales

yeasts.name: Belgian Wit
yeasts.notes: A traditional top-fermenting yeast that has a good balance between fruity esters and warming spice phenolics. The yeast will leave some sweetness and will drop bright if left long enough.
yeasts.bestFor: Witbier, Grand Cru, Spiced Ales and other specialty beers.

yeasts.name: Belgian Wit Ale
yeasts.notes: Phenolic and tart.  The original yeast used to produce Wit in Belgium.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit

yeasts.name: Belgian Wit II
yeasts.notes: Less phenolic than WLP400 (Belgian Wit Ale) but more spicy.  Leaves a little more sweetness and flocculation is higher than WLP400.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit, Spiced Ale, Wheat Ales and Specialty Beers

yeasts.name: Belgian Witbier
yeasts.notes: Tart, slightly phenolic character.  For Wits and Grand Cru.  Tolerates high gravity beers well.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: Belle Saison
yeasts.notes:
Belle Saison produces esters and phenols, which results in beers with fruity, peppery
and spicy flavors and aromas. Belle Saison is suitable for primary fermentation for beers up to 14% ABV. The yeast would require extra nutrition above that level of alcohol such as an addition of 1g/hL of Servomyces.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Bière de Garde, Belgian style beers

yeasts.name: Berliner Blend
yeasts.notes: Designed to be pitched into primary fermentation for Berliner weisse, Gosebier, and other styles where lactic sourness is desired, the blend contains a kolsch yeast, Lactobacillus brevis and Lactobacillus delbreuckii. Suggested fermentation temperature: 70-74ºF.
yeasts.bestFor: Berliner weisse, Gosebier, and other styles where lactic sourness is desired

yeasts.name: Berliner Blend
yeasts.notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.
yeasts.bestFor: Berliner Weisse

yeasts.name: Berliner Weisse Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend of a traditional German Weizen yeast and  Lactobacillus to create a subtle, tart, drinkable beer. Can  take several months to develop tart character.  Perfect for traditional Berliner Weisse.
yeasts.bestFor: Berliner Weisse

yeasts.name: Biere de Garde
yeasts.notes: Ferments well with low to moderate ester production and subtle spiciness. Malty and full on the palate with initial sweetness. Finishes dry and slightly tart.
yeasts.bestFor: Biere de Garde, Saison, Belgian Blonde, Belgian Pale Ale, Belgian Golden Strong

yeasts.name: Bit O' Funk
yeasts.notes: This blend contains the two Saccharomyces strains from blend #1 for primary fermentation and is spiked with Brettanomyces bruxellensis for development of moderate “funk” during a secondary fermentation. The “bit ‘o funkiness” will take extended time (3+ months) to develop.
yeasts.bestFor: Sours, Lambic

yeasts.name: Blanche Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Top fermenting strain for Belgian witbier and wheats.  Spicy and lightly phenolic.
yeasts.bestFor: Wheat beer, Wit

yeasts.name: Bohemian Lager
yeasts.notes: Ferments clean and malty, with rich malty flavor for full gravity pilsners.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Pilsners, Pilsners, German Helles, Bocks

yeasts.name: Bold Red
yeasts.notes: Dominating, strong fermentation characteristics. Alcohol tolerant to 18% (v/v). Ideal for Zinfandel, Pinot Noir, Syrah, or any high sugar must. Good choice for restarting stuck fermentations.
yeasts.bestFor: Apple wine, Cabernet Sauvignon, Dry Mead, Pinot Noir, Rum, Vodka

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Anomala
yeasts.notes: Originally identified by 26S rDNA partial sequencing and was isolated in beer from Adelaide, Australia. This species displays strong fruity esters, moderate barnyard and gradual acidity over time.  Name of Alternate State or Synonym: Dekkera anomala, Brettanomyces intermedius.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: Medium intensity Brett character. Classic strain used in secondary fermentation for Belgian style beers and lambics.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour ales and labics (in secondary)

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: The vrai (true, in French) Brettanomyces bruxellensis Trois. The infamous strain used for all-Brettanomyces fermentations, has a robust, complex sour character with aromas of pear. Best used as a primary fermentation strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour ales and labics.

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: Medium intensity Brett character. Classic strain used in secondary fermentation for Belgian style beers and lambics. One Trappist brewery uses this strain in secondary fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour ales and labics (in secondary)

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: Wild yeast strain isolated from Brussels region of Belgium.  Adds classic sweaty horse hair flavor as well as sourness and cherry-pie like flavor.  Generally used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae after the primary fermentation has begun.  Requires 3-6 mo
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: This strain of wild yeast was isolated from brewery cultures in the Brussels region of Belgium. It produces the classic sweaty horse blanket character and may form a pellicle in bottles or casks. The strain is generally used in conjunction with S. cerevis
yeasts.bestFor: Gueuze, Lambics and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Claussenii
yeasts.notes: Contributes more Brett aroma than flavor. Fruity, pineapple like aroma.
yeasts.bestFor: Sour ales (in secondary)

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Claussenii
yeasts.notes: Low intensity Brett character. Originally isolated from strong English stock beer, in the early 20th century. The Brett flavors produced are more subtle than WLP650 and WLP653. More aroma than flavor contribution. Fruity, pineapple like aroma.
yeasts.bestFor: Sour ales (in secondary)

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Lambicus
yeasts.notes: Wild yeast strain associated with Belgian breweries.  Contributes horsey, old leather flavor complex to Belgian lambics.  Slow growing yeast that takes weeks to ferment and months to develop fully.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic beers

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Lambicus
yeasts.notes: This strain has been described as producing horsey, smoky and spicy flavors. As the name suggests, this strain is found most often in Lambic style beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Lambicus
yeasts.notes: Use in secondary.  High intensity Brett character. Defines the "Brett character": Horsey, smoky and spicy flavors. As the name suggests, this strain is found most often in Lambic style beers, which are spontaneously fermented beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Lambucus
yeasts.notes: This is a wild yeast strain isolated from Belgian lambic beers. It produces a pie cherry-like flavor and sourness with a distinct Brett character. A pellicle may form in bottles or casks. This strain works best in conjunction with other yeast and lactic b
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Naardenensis
yeasts.notes: A unique species of Brettanomyces that creates an abundance of acidity quickly (some acetic acid likely) and may initially display a mousy-like tainted flavor but dissipates over time leading to ester production with hints of strawberry. Aging up to 6 months is recommended. Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-74 F.  Name of Alternate state or synonym: Dekkera naardenensis
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Sour

yeasts.name: Brettanomyces Nanus (Strain 2)
yeasts.notes: Name of Alternate State or Synonym: Eeniella nana. ​This yeast was first isolated from bottled beer in Sweden.
yeasts.bestFor: Sour beers

yeasts.name: Bring On Da FUnk
yeasts.notes: This blend contains the two Saccharomyces strains from blend #1 for primary fermentation and is spiked with Brettanomyces bruxellensis, Brettanomyces lambicus, two Brettanomyces isolates from a Colorado brewery known for its Brett beers, and two Brettanomyces isolates from an “Intense” Belgian source for a funky, fruity and complex brew. Brett character will develop over time. Acid production will increase over time given exposure to oxygen.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales

yeasts.name: British Ale
yeasts.notes: This yeast has higher attenuation than the White Labs English Ale yeast strains.  Produces a malty flavored beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Excellent for all English style ales including bitters, pale ale, porters and brown ale.

yeasts.name: British Ale I
yeasts.notes: Allows malt and hop character to dominate the profile. Highly flocculant and highly attenuative. Ferments well down to 64°F.
yeasts.bestFor: Pale Ales, Amber, ESB, Brown Ales, Strong Ales

yeasts.name: British Ale II
yeasts.notes: A malty and slightly fruity fermentation profile. Highly flocculant — clears well without filtration. Low fermentation temperatures will produce a clean finish with a very low ester profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Whitbread Ale, British Ales, Pales, Bitters

yeasts.name: British Ale II
yeasts.notes: Malty, clean, crisp finish.  Dry flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: British and Canadian Ales, English Bitters

yeasts.name: British Ale III
yeasts.notes: Top cropping yeast that produces malty beers. Great for English style ales including bitter, pale ale, porter, and brown ale. Flocculation is high, and the beer will clear well without filtration. A thorough diacetyl rest is recommended after fermentation is complete. This strain can be a slow starter and fermenter.
yeasts.bestFor: Ringwood Ale, Brown Ales, Bitter, Pale Ale

yeasts.name: British Ale IV
yeasts.notes: Produces classic British bitters with subtle fruity flavors like apple, clover honey and pear. Great for all English styles, IPA’s, bitters, pales, porters and stouts.
yeasts.bestFor: All English styles including Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout and Bitters.

yeasts.name: British Ale Three
yeasts.notes: From a British craft brewery known for its award winning hoppy English ales. Good flocculation, slight esters, excellent for accentuating hop flavor and aroma. This British ale yeast is less flocculent than GY011 and GY031– but still creates a clear beer. Finished beer is dry and crisp with just a hint of esters.
yeasts.bestFor: ESB, Pale Ale, Amber Ale, Bitter, Stout, IPA, Brown Ale

yeasts.name: British Ale V
yeasts.notes: A top cropping strain with a fruity, very light and softly balanced palate. Finishes slightly sweet.
yeasts.bestFor: British Ales, Bitters

yeasts.name: British Ale VI
yeasts.notes: Classic British ale profile with good flocculation and malty flavor characteristics. Finishes crisp, clean and fairly dry.
yeasts.bestFor: British bitters and pale ales.

yeasts.name: British Ale VII
yeasts.notes: Produces ales with a full malt flavor and character, but finishes dry, producing famously balanced beers. Expect moderate nutty and stone-fruit esters. Best used for the production of cask-conditioned bitters, ESB and mild ales. Reliably flocculent, producing bright beer without filtration.
yeasts.bestFor: English IPA, Bitters, Stouts, Browns

yeasts.name: British Ale VIII
yeasts.notes: A classic ESB strain best suited for English style ales including milds, bitters, porters, and English style stouts. Ales produced with this strain tend to be fruity, increasingly so with higher fermentation temperatures of 70-74°F. A thorough diacetyl rest is recommended after fermentation is complete. This yeast will leave a beer very clear, and will leave some residual sweetness.
yeasts.bestFor: English Pale Ale, ESB, India Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Porter, Sweet Stouts and Strong Ales

yeasts.name: British Ale X
yeasts.notes: This yeast produces a malty, but well-balanced beer. Highly flocculent and good choice for English pale ales, English brown ales, and mild ales.
yeasts.bestFor: English pale ales, English brown ales and Mild ales

yeasts.name: British Ale XI
yeasts.notes: Top cropping British style ale yeast with a dry finish. Medium to low fruit and fusel alcohol production. This yeast is well suited for pale ales, ambers, porters, and stouts.
yeasts.bestFor: British ales, pale ales, ambers, porters and stouts.

yeasts.name: British Ale XII
yeasts.notes: A great yeast for malty ales. Produces light fruit and ethanol aromas along with soft, nutty flavors. Exhibits a mild malt profile with a neutral finish. Bright beers are easily achieved without any filtration.
yeasts.bestFor: Extra Special, Strong Bitter, Old Ale, Premium Bitter.

yeasts.name: British Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Fruity, tart, dry crisp finish.  Very well balanced.
yeasts.bestFor: All British Ales, Pales, Bitters, English Strong Ale

yeasts.name: British Ale Yeast One
yeasts.notes: Versatile house strain from a traditional UK brewery.  Strong attenuation over a broad temperature range and low esters make this yeast perfect for a wide variety of styles.  GY011 is a strong flocculator that creates a clear beer.
yeasts.bestFor: British ales, Pale ale, Amber ale, Barley wine, Scotch ale, Bitter, Stout, IPA

yeasts.name: British Ale Yeast Two
yeasts.notes: From a traditional British brewery.  Very flocculent— produces clear beer.   GY031 leaves a slightly sweet malty flavor.   Flavor profile is nearly neutral at lower fermentation temps.  Slight banana/fruit notes appear at higher temps.  Perfect for English style pale ales, stouts, porters, bitters browns etc.
yeasts.bestFor: British Ales, Pale Ale, Amber Ale, Barley Wine, Scotch Ale, Bitter, Stout, IPA

yeasts.name: British Cask
yeasts.notes: Good choice for any cask conditioned British Ale. Produces a nice malt profile and finishes crisp & slightly tart. Low to moderate fruit ester producer that clears well without filtration.
yeasts.bestFor: British Ales

yeasts.name: British Cask Ale
yeasts.notes:
A great choice for any cask conditioned British Ale.  
Produces nice malt profile with a hint of fruit. Finishes dry and slightly tart.
yeasts.bestFor: British Ales

yeasts.name: British Draft Ale
yeasts.notes: Full bodied, well rounded ale yeast with a touch of diacytl.  Emphasizes malt character.  Great for porters and bitters.
yeasts.bestFor: Porters and Bitters.

yeasts.name: British Microbrewery Ale
yeasts.notes: Complex oakey, and fruity ester profile.  Slightly under-attenuated finish leaves some residual malt flavor.  Suitable for low to medium gravity bitters and ales.
yeasts.bestFor: English Bitters and Milds

yeasts.name: British Pale Ale #1
yeasts.notes: Bold, citrusy character which accentuates mineral and hop flavors.  Distinct character of a classic Pale Ale.
yeasts.bestFor: British Pale Ales and Bitters.

yeasts.name: British Pale Ale #2
yeasts.notes: Smooth, full bodied, well roundd ale yeast. Mild esters.  Strong ferementer suitable for strong or spiced ales.  Accentuates caramel and malt flavors.
yeasts.bestFor: British Pale Ale, other British Ales

yeasts.name: British Real Ale
yeasts.notes: Great for real pub bitters.  Has a complex, woody flavor and musty ester profile that characterizes real ale.  Underattenuating to leave mild sweetness to the finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Bitters and other English Ales

yeasts.name: Brussels Bruxellensis
yeasts.notes: Produces classic Brett “Barnyard” characteristics plus some subtle fruity aroma and moderate acidity.  Adds a tart complexity to any beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Gueuze, Lambics and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Brux Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend of Brettanomyces yeast that produces stone fruit esters and a hint of barnyard. Creates a moderate amount of acid that adds a tart complexity to the brew.  This blend is highly attenuative if left for long periods of time but ferments more slowly than a typical ale yeast.  Use GB156 in a primary if fermented for 2-3 weeks or for conditioning a fermented beer during aging. This blend is highly attenuative but tends to ferment about ½ as fast as a typical ale strain
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Budvar Lager
yeasts.notes: Classic pilsner lager yeast.  Malty nose and subtle fruit.  Rich malt profile, but dry crisp finish.  Hop character accentuated by dry finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Pilsner, Classic Pilsners, Dortmunder and Light Lagers

yeasts.name: BugCountry
yeasts.notes: With over 20 different isolates combined for fermentation to overwhelm the senses, this blend is the mother-bugger for wild ales. Like the BugFarm, Brettanomyces dominants the overall population, however, other wild yeast seen in spontaneous fermentations are also included (such as Pichia  and Kloeckera ).  Several strains of Saccharomyces, Lactobacillus and Pediococcus round out this large and complex culture.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Sours

yeasts.name: BugFarm
yeasts.notes: A mixed culture of wild yeast and lactic bacteria to emulate sour or wild beers such as lambic-style ales. Over time displays a citrus sourness and barnyard funk profile. Contains yeast (Saccharomyces, Brettanomyces) and lactic bacteria (Lactobacillus, Pediococcus). The "Brett" population is typically >50% of the culture pitch. The blend of strains change every calendar year for those who like to blend or have solera projects.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic

yeasts.name: Burton Ale
yeasts.notes: Burton-on-trent yeast produces a complex character.  Flavors include apple, pear, and clover honey.
yeasts.bestFor: All English styles including Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout and Bitters.

yeasts.name: Burton Union
yeasts.notes: Produces a bold, citrusy character which accentuates mineral and hop flavors. Well suited for classic English pale ales and ESB.  Attenuation 73-75%; fermentation temperature: 64-69F.
yeasts.bestFor: English pale ales, ESB

yeasts.name: C2C American Farmhouse
yeasts.notes: A “coast to coast” blend of a saison strain from a famous Northeast U.S. brewery and a Brettanomyces strain from a Northwest U.S. brewery.  The blend results in a fast developing fruity and funky farmhouse ale.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ales

yeasts.name: CBC-1
yeasts.notes:
CBC-1 is suitable for primary fermentation for fruit beers and Champagne-like beers
up to 12% ABV. Neutral flavor and aroma. Alcohol resistant. Not able to utilize maltotriose.
yeasts.bestFor: CBC-1 can be used to referment any type of ale. Used for cask and bottle conditioning.

yeasts.name: Cabernet Red Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes:
High temperature tolerance. Moderate fermentation speed. Excellent for full-bodied red wines, ester production complements flavor. WLP760 is also suitable for Merlot, Chardonnay, Chianti, Chenin Blanc, and Sauvignon Blanc.
Alcohol Tolerance: 16%
yeasts.bestFor: Merlot, Chardonnay, Chianti, Chenin Blanc, and Sauvignon Blanc

yeasts.name: California Ale
yeasts.notes:
Very clean flavor, balance and stability.  Accentuates hop flavor
Versitile - can be used to make any style ale.
yeasts.bestFor: American Style Ales, Ambers, Pale Ales, Brown Ale, Strong Ale

yeasts.name: California Ale V
yeasts.notes: Similar to White Labs California Ale Yeast, but slightly lower attenuation leaves a fuller bodied beer.
yeasts.bestFor: American style Pales, Ambers, Browns, IPAs, American Strong Ale

yeasts.name: California Esteem (Gold)
yeasts.notes: Use for California Common Beers (aka Steam Beer).  Leaves a slightly estery, well attenuated finish.  Quite distinct in flavor.  Can also be used for complex porters.
yeasts.bestFor: California Common Beer, American or Robust porters
