yeasts.name: California Lager
yeasts.notes: A unique lager strain that has the ability to ferment at ale temperatures without the associated off flavours. Extended lagering periods are also not required.
yeasts.bestFor: Suitable for California Common and any lager fermented at ambient (ale) temperatures.

yeasts.name: California Lager
yeasts.notes: Suited for 19th century California style beers.  Lagers at high temperature and produces malty, clear beers.
yeasts.bestFor: California common beers, Steam Beer

yeasts.name: California Pub Ale
yeasts.notes: For that classic U.S. small brewery flavor. CL-50 produces terrific American red & pale ale styles. While attenuation is normal, this yeast produces a big, soft, well rounded malt flavor that really lets caramel malt flavors shine.
yeasts.bestFor: California and other American ales

yeasts.name: Canadian Ale
yeasts.notes: Clean, strong fermenting, well attenuated ale yeast that leaves a pleasant, fruity, complex finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Light Canadian Ales, Bitish Bitter, Pale Ale, Porters

yeasts.name: Champagne Yeast
yeasts.notes: Can tolerate alcohol up to 17%.  For Barley Wine or Meads.
yeasts.bestFor: Wine, Mead and Cider

yeasts.name: Chardonnay White Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: Dry wine yeast. Slight ester production, low sulfur dioxide production. Enhances varietal character. WLP730 is a good choice for all white and blush wines, including Chablis, Chenin Blanc, Semillon, and Sauvignon Blanc. Fermentation speed is moderate.  Al
yeasts.bestFor: Chardonnay Wine

yeasts.name: Cider
yeasts.notes: Crisp and dry fermenting yeast with big, fruity finish. Creates a nice balance for all types of apples, pears, and other fruit. Allows fruit character to dominate the profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Apple wine, Common cider, English cider

yeasts.name: Classic British Ale
yeasts.notes: Complex ale with British tones and fruit like esters.  Works well in high gravity ales such as scottish heavy as well.
yeasts.bestFor: Bitters, Porters, Scottish Heavy Ales.

yeasts.name: Cooper Ale
yeasts.notes: General purpose dry ale yeast with a very good reputation.  Produces significant fruity flavors.  No phenolics.  Clean, fruity finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Most ales.

yeasts.name: Copenhagen Lager
yeasts.notes: Clean, crisp north European lager yeast. Not as malty as the southern European lager yeast strains.
yeasts.bestFor: European style Pilsners, European style Dark Lagers, Vienna, and American style lagers.

yeasts.name: Cream Ale Yeast Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend of ale and lager yeast strains that work together to create a clean, light American lager style ale.  A pleasing estery aroma may be perceived.  Hop flavors and bitterness are slightly subdued.  Slight sulfer will be produced during fermentation f
yeasts.bestFor: Cream Ale, Hybrids

yeasts.name: Cry Havoc
yeasts.notes: Licensed by White Labs from Charlie Papazian, author of "The Complete Joy of Home Brewing".  This yeast was used to brew many of his original recipes.  Diverse strain can ferment at ale and lager temps.
yeasts.bestFor: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.

yeasts.name: Czech Budejovice Lager
yeasts.notes: Dry and crisp with low diacetyl production.  From Southern Czech Republic.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Style Pilsner

yeasts.name: Czech Pilsner
yeasts.notes: Bottom fermenting yeast from a world famous Czech pilsner.  Produces a dry, clean beer.   Perfect for pilsner and other lager styles.  This yeast is flocculent and produces a very clear beer.  Robust attenuation in beer up to 16-17˚ Plato.  Moderate to poor attenuation in very high gravity beers (over 20˚ Plato).
yeasts.bestFor: Pilsners, Lagers

yeasts.name: Czech Pilsner Lager
yeasts.notes: Classic Pilsner strain.  Creates a dry but malty finish.  Perfect for Pilsners and bocks.  Some sulfur produced, but will fade with time.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian and American Pilsner, Bocks, Oktoberfest, Marzen

yeasts.name: DIPA Ale
yeasts.notes: Ale strain isolated from a famous double IPA brewed in Vermont. Produces a unique ester profile reminiscent of peaches. This strain complements an aggressive use of hops.
yeasts.bestFor: IIPA, IPA, American Wheat, Pale Ale, Bitter, West Coast Amber, ESB

yeasts.name: Danish Lager
yeasts.notes: An excellent choice for Dortmund-style lagers. Ferments crisp and dry with a soft, rounded profile that accentuates hop characteristics.
yeasts.bestFor: Dortmund/Export Lagers

yeasts.name: Danish Lager
yeasts.notes: Rich, Dortmund style, with a crisp, dry finish.  Soft profile accentuates hop flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Dortmund/Export Lagers

yeasts.name: Diamond Lager
yeasts.notes: Diamond Lager yeast originated in Germany and is used in a number of commercial breweries to produce various lagers.
yeasts.bestFor: Lagers

yeasts.name: Dirty Dozen Brett Blend
yeasts.notes: Twelve (12) different isolates of atypical yeast exhibiting high production of barnyard "funk" and esters. Dryness, ripe fruit, and acidity will be encountered over a period of months and over time (>1 yr), may display gueuze-like qualities in complexity. Contains various isolates from lambic-producers, B. bruxellensis, B. anomala, B. lambicus, and B. naardenensis.  For those who want the most from "Brett" yeast, whether a 100% fermentation is desired or adding to secondary aging projects.  Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-74 F. Attenuation high.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Sour, Gueze

yeasts.name: Doric Ale
yeasts.notes: Good reputation.  Reliable clean finish for a dry yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales

yeasts.name: Dry / Fortified
yeasts.notes: Mild toast and vanilla nose. Mild fruit profile with balanced depth and complexity. Very dry finish. Dry red and white wines, add brandy for classic ports. Also used for big red wines and high sugar musts.
yeasts.bestFor: Brandy, Chianti, Cognac, Merlot, Port, Zinfandel

yeasts.name: Dry Belgian Ale
yeasts.notes:
Dry Belgian Ale is single strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae isolated from a unique golden strong ale. The profile is a complex and balanced mix of apple, pear and light citrus fruit with some mild spicy and peppery notes. The apparent attenuation of this strain ranges anywhere from 85-100%, depending upon the mash profile and the grist composition.

For a yeast that's as dry as it is, it creates beers with a surprising amount of balance even without the use of specialty grains or adjuncts. While we haven't completed our own tests in house, this yeast is used at the brewery from which it was isolated to make big beers that are in the neighborhood of 12-16% ABV and sufficiently dry. Use Dry Belgian Ale as a primary fermenter in any big Belgian beer, or to unstick that pesky stuck fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian ales

yeasts.name: Dry English Ale
yeasts.notes: Clean, Highly flocculant, and highly attentive yeast.  Similar to White labs English Ale yeast, but more attentive.  Suitable for high gravity ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Pale Ales, Amber, ESB, Brown Ales, Strong Ales

yeasts.name: Dry Mead
yeasts.notes: Best choice for dry mead. Used in many award winning meads. Low foaming with little or no sulfur production. Use additional nutrients for mead making.
yeasts.bestFor: Braggot, Dry mead

yeasts.name: Dry Wine
yeasts.notes: Used in many white wine fermentations and also some red wines. Also used for secondary fermentation of barley wine. Ferments crisp and dry, ideal for base wines in making sparkling wine. Low foaming, excellent barrel fermentation, good flocculating characteristics.
yeasts.bestFor: Asti type, Brandy, Cabernet Franc,Cava type, Chardonnay, Cognac, Armagnac, Common Perry, Dolcetto, Dry Mead, Eau de Vie, French Cider, Grappa/Marc/Bagaceira, Melon (Muscadet), Muscat Blanc, Pinot Gris, Pinotage, Red ,Bordeaux type blends, Rum, Scotch, Sémillon, Seyval Blanc, Sherry, Soave type ,blends, Sparkling wine, Traditional Perry, Trebbiano/Ugni Blanc, Vermouth, Vodka, Whiskey

yeasts.name: Dusseldorf Alt Yeast
yeasts.notes: Traditional Alt yeast from Dusseldorf, Germany.  Produces clean, slightly sweet alt beers.  Does not accentuate hop flavor like WLP029 does.
yeasts.bestFor: Alt biers, Dusseldorf Alts, German Ales

yeasts.name: East Coast Ale
yeasts.notes: This strain can be used to reproduce many of the American versions of classic beer styles. Similar neutral character of West Coast Ale I, but less attenuation, less accentuation of hop bitterness, slightly less flocculation, and a little tartness. Very clean and low esters. Great yeast for golden, blonde, honey, pales and German alt style ales.
yeasts.bestFor: American Ales, Golden ales, Blonde Ale, Pale Ale and German Alt styles

yeasts.name: East Coast Ale
yeasts.notes: White labs "Brewer Patriot" strain can be used to reproduce many of the American versions of classic beer styles.  Very clean with low esters.
yeasts.bestFor: American Ales, Golden ales, Blonde Ale, Pale Ale and German Alt styles

yeasts.name: East European Lager
yeasts.notes: Smooth, rich, creamy character.  Emphasizes big malt flavor and clean finish.  Full but smooth malt character.
yeasts.bestFor: Marzens, Oktoberfest

yeasts.name: Edinburgh Ale
yeasts.notes: Malty strong ale yeast.  Reproduces complex, malty, flavorful schottish ales.  Hop character comes through well.
yeasts.bestFor: Strong Scottish style ales,  ESB, Irish Reds

yeasts.name: Edme Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Quick starting dry yeast with a good reputation. Produces some fruity ester. Highly attentive, so it will likely produce a slightly dry taste.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales requiring high attenuation.

yeasts.name: English Ale
yeasts.notes: Classic ESB strain best for English style milds, bitters, porters and English style stouts.  Leaves a clear beer with some residual sweetness.
yeasts.bestFor: English Pale Ale, ESB, India Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Porter, Sweet Stouts and Strong Ales

yeasts.name: English Cider Yeast
yeasts.notes: Classic Cider yeast.  Ferments dry, but retains apple flavor.  Some sulfer produced during fermentation will fade with age.
yeasts.bestFor: Cider, Wine and High Gravity Beer

yeasts.name: English Special Bitter
yeasts.notes: Similar to 1968, slightly less flocculent. Produces light fruit ethanol aroma. Mild malt with a neutral soft finish. Very clean.
yeasts.bestFor: Extra Special, Bitters

yeasts.name: Essex Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Flavorful British yeast with a drier finish than many ale yeasts.  Bready and fruity in character.  Well suited for top cropping (collecting).  Does not flocculate as much as WLP005 or WLP002.
yeasts.bestFor: British milds, pale ales, bitters, stouts.

yeasts.name: European Ale
yeasts.notes: Malty, Northern European ale yeast.  Low ester production, low sulfer, gives a clean profile.  Low attenuation contributes to malty taste.
yeasts.bestFor: Alt, Kolsch, malty English Ales, Fruit beers

yeasts.name: European Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Very malty flavor characteristic of Bavarian/Munich Ales.  Complex character.
yeasts.bestFor: European Ales, German Ales, Alts, Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Kolsch

yeasts.name: European Lager II
yeasts.notes: Clean, dry flavor profile for aggressively hopped pilsners.  Dry finish, mild aroma, slight sulfur production.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Pilsner, American Pilsner, Helles, Dunkel

yeasts.name: Extreme Fermentation
yeasts.notes: A very good choice for alcohol tolerance and stuck fermentations. Produces a very clean, dry profile, low ester formation and other volatile aromatics.
yeasts.bestFor: Brandy, Cognac, Rum, Scotch, Vodka

yeasts.name: Farmhouse Blend
yeasts.notes: A saison blend (ECY08) with a wild isolate from a small but fascinating producer of Saison. Can produce a funky and acidic farmhouse ale particularly when a secondary fermentable is added (i.e. priming sugar or fruit).
yeasts.bestFor: Saison

yeasts.name: Farmhouse Sour
yeasts.notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.
yeasts.bestFor: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales

yeasts.name: Fast Souring Lacto
yeasts.notes:
Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures.  You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables.  More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring.

We recommend brewing with GB110 in one of three ways.  I)  “Hot Start”:  Pitch GB110 to wort at 98 F with little or no hops for 48-72 hrs.  Wort may be soured before kettle boil or after.  If soured before kettle boil,  boil with hop additions as usual.  If soured after kettle boil cool wort and pitch yeast.  II)  “Co-Pitch”:  Pitch GB110 into a primary with yeast of your choice at 68-72 F.  Wort that is less than 1050 and 7 IBU will typically be very sour in 2-3 weeks.    III)  “Secondary”:  Pitch GB110 after primary fermentation for an aged sour.  Souring by this method typically requires several months.  Adding simple sugars or fruit etc. will enhance souring in the secondary.
yeasts.bestFor: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales

yeasts.name: Flemish Ale
yeasts.notes: A unique blend of yeast and lactic bacteria producing sour beers with leather, fruit, and cherry stone flavors. Perfect for Flemish reds, oud brune, other sour ales. The blend contains a base Belgian yeast, several Brettanomyces, Lactobacilli, and Pediococcus.
yeasts.bestFor: Flemish red, oud brune, sour beers

yeasts.name: Flor Sherry Yeast
yeasts.notes: This yeast develops a film (flor) on the surface of the wine. Creates   green almond, granny smith and nougat characteristics found in sherry. Can also be used for Port, Madeira and other sweet styles. For use in secondary fermentation. Slow fermentor. Al
yeasts.bestFor: Sherry wine yeast

yeasts.name: Forbidden Fruit
yeasts.notes: Phenolic profile with subdued fruitiness.  Available seasonally.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: Franconian Dark Lager
yeasts.notes:
Franconian Dark Lager is a single strain of Saccharomyces pastorianus that hails from the Franconia region of Germany. This yeast exhibits a short lag time and has flavor profile characteristics that complement dark, roasted malts. The dark malt complementing nature of this yeast makes it a perfect fit for any big, malt driven dark lagers.

We recommend a brief diacetyl rest at ~ 60-65 ºF (2-3 days) at the end of primary fermentation. An extended lagering phase at 33-35 ºF will encourage the yeast to settle and create a clean profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Dark Lagers

yeasts.name: French Red Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: Classic Bordeaux yeast for red wine fermentations. Moderate fermentation characteristics. Tolerates lower fermentation temperatures. Rich, smooth flavor profile.  Alcohol Tolerance: 17%
yeasts.bestFor: Bordeaux

yeasts.name: French Saison
yeasts.notes: Versatile strain that produces Saison or farmhouse style beers as well as other Belgian style beers that are highly aromatic (estery), peppery, spicy and citrusy. This strain enhances the use of spices and aroma hops, and is extremely attenuative but leaves an unexpected silky and rich mouthfeel. This strain can also be used to re-start stuck fermentations or in high gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: French and Belgian Saison or Farmhouse ales

yeasts.name: French Saison
yeasts.notes: A very versatile strain that produces Saison or farmhouse style biers as well as other Belgian style beers that are highly aromatic (estery), peppery, spicy and citrusy. This strain enhances the use of spices and aroma hops, and is extremely attenuative b
yeasts.bestFor: French and Belgian Saison or Farmhouse ales

yeasts.name: French Saison Ale
yeasts.notes: This yeast is famous for its clean flavors, balance and ability to be used in almost any style of ale. It accentuates the hop flavors and is extremely versatile.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison

yeasts.name: French Sasion
yeasts.notes: French Saison yeast is an exceptional, highly attenuative top-fermenting ale yeast, creating distinctive beers with spicy, fruity and peppery notes. Ideal for fermentation of farmhouse style beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Saisons and farmhouse style beers up to 14% ABV

yeasts.name: French White Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: Classic yeast for white wine fermentation. Slow to moderate fermenter and foam producer. Gives an enhanced creamy texture.  Alcohol Tolerance: 16%
yeasts.bestFor: French white wines

yeasts.name: Fruity White
yeasts.notes: Produces extremely fruity profile, high ester formation, bready aromas with vanilla notes. Allows fruit character to dominate aroma and flavor profile. Finishes slightly sweet and soft.
yeasts.bestFor: Fruity wines

yeasts.name: GF All American Ale
yeasts.notes: Popular all purpose American ale style now in a Gluten Free strain.  Produces beers that are nutty, clean with a slight tart finish.  Ferment warmer to accentuate hops and add fruitiness or ferment cold for clean light citrus character.
yeasts.bestFor: American Amber, Brown, IPA, Pale ales and stouts.  Blondes and fruit beers.

yeasts.name: German Ale
yeasts.notes: Crisp, dry finish with a mild flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: German Ales, Alts, Kolsch, Dry Stout

yeasts.name: German Ale II
yeasts.notes: Strong sulfer component will reduce with aging.  Clean flavor, but with more ester production than regular German Ale Yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, Alt and German Pale Ales

yeasts.name: German Ale/Kolsch
yeasts.notes: Great for light beers.  Accentuates hop flavors.  Slight sulfer flavor will fade with age and leave a clean, lager like ale.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, Altbiers, Pale Ales, Blonde and Honey Ales

yeasts.name: German Bock
yeasts.notes: This yeast produces a beer that is well balanced between malt and hop character. The malt profile makes it well suited for Bocks, Doppelbocks, and Oktoberfest style beers. Also good for Helles style lager beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Bocks, Doppelbocks, Oktoberfest, Vienna, Helles, some American Pilsners

yeasts.name: German Bock Lager
yeasts.notes: Produces beer that has balanced malt and hop character.  From Southern Bavaria.
yeasts.bestFor: Bocks, Doppelbocks, Oktoberfest, Vienna, Helles, some American Pilsners

yeasts.name: German Lager
yeasts.notes: Bottom fermenting German yeast used in commercial breweries around the world.  Produces a slightly sweeter but clean beer with a malty finish.   Perfect for pilsners, märzen, Festbier etc .  May require a diacetyl rest after fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Lagers, Keller Bier, Marzen, Schwarzbier, Bock, Pilsner

yeasts.name: German Lager
yeasts.notes: Very malty and clean.  One of the world's most popular lager yeasts.
yeasts.bestFor: German Marzen, Pilsner, Lagers, Oktoberfest beers.

yeasts.name: German Lager I
yeasts.notes: The most widely used lager strain in the world. This strain produces a distinct malty profile with some ester character and a crisp finish. A versatile strain, that is great to use with lagers or Pilsners for fermentations in the 45-55°F range. It may also be used for Common beer production with fermentations at 65-68°F. A thorough diacetyl rest is recommended after fermentation is complete.
yeasts.bestFor: German Marzen, Pilsner, Lagers, Oktoberfest beers.

yeasts.name: German Lager II
yeasts.notes: Characterized by a malty finish and balanced aroma. It is a strong fermenter, produces slight sulfur, and low diacetyl.
yeasts.bestFor: German Pilsner, Helles, Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bocks

yeasts.name: German Lager III
yeasts.notes: This yeast finishes malty with a slight ester profile. Used in beers such as Oktoberfest, Bock, and Dark Lagers.
yeasts.bestFor: Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bock and Dark Lagers.

yeasts.name: German Lager X
yeasts.notes: Classic yeast from a famous Bavarian monastery. This strain develops a creamy, malty beer profile with low sulfur production and low esters.
yeasts.bestFor: Helles, Oktoberfest, Bock, and Dunkel.

yeasts.name: German Weiss
yeasts.notes: Milder than German Wheat #1, this strain still produces the desired clove and phenol character, but to a lesser degree.  Full, earthy character.
yeasts.bestFor: Weiss, Weizen, other Southern German Wheat styles

yeasts.name: German Wheat
yeasts.notes: Subtle flavor profile.  Sharp, fruity, crisp, sherry like flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian Weizen

yeasts.name: German Wheat BT
yeasts.notes: Top fermenting Weizenbier yeast.  Intensely spicy, clovey and phenolic.  High attenuation.
yeasts.bestFor: Weizen, Weizenbocks

yeasts.name: Golden Gate Lager
yeasts.notes: Lager yeast used to create the California Common beer style.  Ferments unusually high for a lager strain and still retains a lager sensibility (up to 68˚F).  This yeast leaves a slightly sweeter beer than our other lager yeast— perfect for creating a subtle, malty undertone against a clean lager background.  Creates a moderate amount of sulfide under some conditions that will dissipate with a short rest.  Fermentations at traditional lager temperatures may be slow.  Recommended 55˚- 68˚F
yeasts.bestFor: California Common, Cream Ale, Stout

yeasts.name: Golden Pear Belgian
yeasts.notes: Traditional yeast from the originator of the Belgian Golden Strong Ale style.   Robust attenuation makes this yeast an excellent choice for low or high gravity belgian and farmhouse style ales.  Leaves a dry, slightly tart finish with an estery profile reminiscent of apple and pear with a subdued level of spicy phenolics.  This yeast produces a moderate amount of sulfide  that will dissipate quickly with conditioning.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Strong Ale, Farmhouse Ale, Tripel, Saison, Dubbel, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Grand Cru
yeasts.notes: Widely used strain in the production of Witbier, Grand Cru, sweet mead and cider. Produces spicy phenolics which are balanced nicely by a complex ester profile. The subtle fruit character and dry tart finish will complement wheat malt, orange peel and spice additions typical of Wits.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru

yeasts.name: HP Lager
yeasts.notes: Use to ferment lager beer in one week! Ferment at room temperature (62-68°F) under 1.0 bar (14.7 PSI) until final gravity is obtained, generally in one week. Lager the beer at 35¡F, 15 PSI, for 3-5 days, to condition. Sulfur production is strong first 2 days, then disappears by day 5. Do not need to carbonate, since at 1 bar entire time.
yeasts.bestFor: Lager

yeasts.name: Hefeweizen Ale
yeasts.notes: The most popular German wheat beer strain used worldwide. Produces a balance of banana esters and clove phenolics that can be skewed depending on various conditions – e.g., increased ester production through increasing the fermentation temperature, increasing the wort density, and decreasing the pitch rate or over pitching to reduce or nearly eliminate banana character. Decreasing the ester level will allows higher clove character to be perceived. Sulfur is commonly produced, but will dissipate with conditioning. This strain is very powdery and will remain in suspension for an extended amount of time following attenuation. This is true top cropping yeast and requires fermenter headspace of 33%.
yeasts.bestFor: German style wheat beers.  Weiss, Weizen, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Hefeweizen Ale
yeasts.notes: Produces the banana and clove nose traditionally associated with German Wheat beers.  Also produces desired cloudy look.
yeasts.bestFor: German style wheat beers.  Weiss, Weizen, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Hefeweizen Ale II
yeasts.notes: Flocculent German wheat beer strain. Results in bright beer without filtration. Produces a balance of banana esters and clove phenolics. The balance can be manipulated towards ester production through increasing fermentation temperature, increasing the wort density, and decreasing the pitch rate. Over pitching can result in a near complete loss of banana character. Sulfur is commonly produced, but will dissipate with conditioning.
yeasts.bestFor: German style Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Hefeweizen IV Ale
yeasts.notes: Large clove and phenolic aroma, but with minimal banana flavor.  Citrus and apricot notes.  Crisp and drinkable, with some sulfur production.
yeasts.bestFor: German style Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Hessian Pils
yeasts.notes:
Hessian Pils is a single strain of Saccharomyces pastorianus that hails from the Hess region of Germany. It exhibits everything you want in a great Pilsner yeast: it's a clean fermenter with relatively low ester formation, exhibits a short lag time, ferments wort quickly and attenuates well, even at the low end of the temperature range. These characteristics allow the malt and hop profile to really shine, and creates a crisp finished beer.

We recommend a brief diacetyl rest at ~ 60-65 ºF (2-3 days) at the end of primary fermentation. An extended lagering phase at 33-35 ºF will encourage the yeast to settle and create a clean profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Pilsner

yeasts.name: High Gravity Ale
yeasts.notes: An English yeast that can ferment up to 25% alcohol. Produces ester character that increases with increasing gravity. Malt character dominates at lower gravities.
yeasts.bestFor: Very high gravity beers and barley wine up to 25% alcohol.

yeasts.name: HotHead Ale
yeasts.notes: An ale strain of Norwegian origin that has an astoundingly wide temperature range (62F-98F) with little difference in flavor profile across the whole range.  Temperature control is unnecessary with this strain.  It has a unique fruitiness that makes it complementary to modern hop varieties.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales

yeasts.name: Irish Ale
yeasts.notes: A popular choice for dark beers and high gravity beers. Beers fermented in the lower temperature range produce a dry, crisp profile with subtle fruitiness. Fruit and complex esters will increase when fermentation temperatures are above 64°F
yeasts.bestFor: Irish Ales, Stouts, Porters, Browns, Reds and Pale Ale

yeasts.name: Irish Ale
yeasts.notes: Dry diacetyl, fruity flavor characteristic of stouts.  Full bodied, dry, clean flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Irish Dry Stouts, Porter, Scottish Ale, Brown Ale, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

yeasts.name: Irish Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Excellent for Irish Stouts.  Produces slight hint of diacetyl balanced by a light fruitiness and a slightly dry crispness.
yeasts.bestFor: Irish Ales, Stouts, Porters, Browns, Reds and Pale Ale

yeasts.name: Irish Dry Stout
yeasts.notes: Top fermenting yeast which leaves a recognizable slightly woody character to Dry Stouts.  Vinous almost lactic character that blends well with roast malts.  High attenuation.
yeasts.bestFor: Dry Stouts

yeasts.name: Irish Stout
yeasts.notes: From one of the most famous stouts in the world.  Creates a crisp, dry beer with a subtle fruity profile and a slightly tangy finish.  Makes an amazing stout or porter but is also great for red, amber and even pale ales.  This ale yeast is a robust fermenter perfect for high gravity brews and settles out well enough to create a relatively clear beer.
yeasts.bestFor: Stout, Porter, Imperial Stout, Amber Ale, Red Ale, English Pale Ale

yeasts.name: Italian Red
yeasts.notes: Rich, very big and bold, well rounded profile. Nice soft fruit character with dry crisp finish. Excellent choice for most Italian grape varieties.
yeasts.bestFor: Chianti, Fruit cider, Apple wine

yeasts.name: Kellerbier
yeasts.notes: This yeast exhibits a clean, crisp lager in the traditional northern German character. Use in German pilsners including Kellerbier. Recommended fermentation temperature: 46-54F; attenuation: 74-76%.
yeasts.bestFor: Northern German Lagers, Pilsners

yeasts.name: Klassic Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Traditional English Ale style yeast.  Produces ester character, and allows hop flavor through.  Leaves a slightly sweet malt character in ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Bitters, milds, porters stouts and scottish ale styles.

yeasts.name: Kolsch
yeasts.notes: Produces mild sulfer flavor which smooths with time to a clean attenuated flavor.  Mineral and malt characters come through well.  Clean, lightly yeasty flavor and aroma in the finish.
yeasts.bestFor: German Kolsch

yeasts.name: Kolsch
yeasts.notes: True top cropping yeast strain from a traditional brewery in Cologne, Germany. Beers will exhibit some of the fruity character of an ale, with a clean lager like profile. It produces low or no detectable levels of diacetyl. May also be used to produce quick-conditioning pseudo-lager beers and ferments well at cold 55-60°F range. This powdery strain results in yeast that remain in suspension post fermentation. It requires filtration or additional settling time to produce bright beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, European Ales

yeasts.name: Kolsch II
yeasts.notes: An appropriate yeast for light beers such as kölsch, alt, blond and honey. Accentuates hop flavors. The slight sulfur produced during fermentation will disappear with age and leave a clean, lager-like ale.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, Altbiers, Pale Ales, Blonde and Honey Ales

yeasts.name: Kolsch Yeast
yeasts.notes: Very malty flavor with mix of lager and ale character.  Crisp, clean finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, European Ales

yeasts.name: Kolschbier
yeasts.notes: Produces a clean lager-like profile at ale fermentation temperatures. Smooth mineral and malt flavors come through with a clean, lightly yeasty flavor and aroma in the finish. Recommended fermentation temperature: 58-66F; attenuation:75-78%.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch

yeasts.name: Kölsch
yeasts.notes: From one of the oldest Kölsch breweries in Köln.  Fermenting under 65˚F produces a very clean, crisp beer with a touch of ester.  Perfect for Kölsch or any style where a dry, clean profile is desired.  GY021 produces a moderate amount of sulfide that will dissipate completely.
yeasts.bestFor: Kolsch, Pale Ale, Alt, IPA, Cream Ale, Amber

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus
yeasts.notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from a Belgian brewery. This culture produces moderate levels of acidity and is commonly found in many types of beers including gueuze, lambics, sour brown ales and Berliner Weisse. It is always used in conjunction with S.cer
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sout beers (secondary)

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus Bacteria
yeasts.notes: Bacteria for use in secondary.  This lactic acid bacteria produces moderate levels of acidity and sour flavors found in lambics, Berliner Weiss, sour brown ale and gueze.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze (secondary)

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus Blend
yeasts.notes: This blend contains two Lactobacillus species — brevis and plantarum — giving the blend a wide active temperature range. The Lactobacillus plantarum strain was isolated in collaboration with Marz Community Brewing from a starter inoculated with whole malt grains. It sours efficiently at lower temperatures (65F-100F) compared to other Lactobacillus species. To use the blend for kettle souring a 5 gallon batch, prepare a 1 liter starter of approximately 1.040 specific gravity and pour contents of pouch into unhopped starter. Incubate 24-48 hours at room temperature to increase cell count. Prepare wort as normal and cool to 75-95F. Pitch Lactobacillus starter into unhopped wort and allow to sour to desired level. Maximum levels of sourness should develop within 48 hours. There is no need to hold the temperatures at the high end of the range for effective souring due to the efficient action of plantarum at lower temperatures. When desired sourness is achieved, re-boil wort to kill Lactobacillus.  Add hops at this time if desired.  This blend is extremely hop sensitive.  Souring may not occur in worts with 2 or more IBUs.  Cool wort and pitch yeast to complete fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus Brevis
yeasts.notes: This strain of L. brevis was originally isolated from kefir. Bright acidity and hop-tolerant. Fermnetation temperature 60 - 80 F.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze (secondary)

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus Brevis
yeasts.notes: WLP672 Lactobacillus brevis is a rod-shaped bacteria used for souring beers. Typically produces more lactic acid than Lactobacillus delbrueckii. Great addition to any sour program!
yeasts.bestFor: Sours

yeasts.name: Lactobacillus Delbrueckii
yeasts.notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium.  Produces mild acidity and sourness found in many types of Belgian beers.  Always used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae and wild yeasts.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian gueze, lambic, sour brown ales, and Berliner Weisse.

yeasts.name: Lager I
yeasts.notes: Produces a malty nose with subtle fruit tones and a rich malt profile on the palate. Finishes malty but dry, well balanced and crisp. Hop character comes through in the finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Pilsner, Classic Pilsners, Dortmunder and Light Lagers

yeasts.name: Lager Yeast
yeasts.notes: A dry lager yeast with high attenuation.  Ferments clean and malty.
yeasts.bestFor: Lagers

yeasts.name: Lalvin - K1V-1116
yeasts.notes: Used for white grape varieties.  Rapid starter with constant and complete fermentation. Capable of surviving difficult conditions such as low nutrient or high SO2 levels.  Has low volatile action.
yeasts.bestFor: Souvingnon Blanc, Chenin Blanc and Seyval.

yeasts.name: Lalvin 71B-1122
yeasts.notes: Rapid starter with constant and complete fermentation. Ability to metabolize high amounts (20-40%) of malic acid. Partial metabolism of malic acid helps soften the wine.  May produce significant esters, making it a good choice for concentrates.
yeasts.bestFor: Young wines such as nouveau, blush and sugar white.

yeasts.name: Lalvin D-47
yeasts.notes: Recommended for white variety wines such as Chardonnay and Rose as well as Mead.  Low foaming, quick fermenting, forming a compact lees at the end of fermentation.  Use yeast nutrients if making mead.  Saccharomyces Cerevisiae.
yeasts.bestFor: White wines such as Chardonnay and Rose.  Also good for mead.

yeasts.name: Lalvin EC-1118
yeasts.notes: Low production of foam, volatile acid and H2S.  Ferments over a wide temperature range. High alcohol tolerance, compact lees and good flocculation.  Relatively neutral flavor and aroma.
yeasts.bestFor: All types of wine and also cider.

yeasts.name: Lalvin RC 212 (Bourgovin)
yeasts.notes: RC212 recommended for red variety wines and high gravity beers.  Alcohol tolerance in the 12-14% range.  Low foaming and moderate speed fermenting.  Saccharomyces Cerevisiae.
yeasts.bestFor: Red wines.

yeasts.name: Liberty Bell
yeasts.notes: A top fermenting ale yeast suitable for a wide variety of hoppy and distinctive style beers. This strain produces light, delicate fruity esters and helps to develop malt character.
yeasts.bestFor: Suitable for both English and American Pale Ales, Extra Special Bitters, Golden Ales and more.

yeasts.name: London
yeasts.notes: Produces a clean, well balanced ale.  Medium attenuation preserves some beer complexity.
yeasts.bestFor: Well balanced British style ales.

yeasts.name: London Ale
yeasts.notes: Highly attenuative with a rich mineral profile. Some fruitiness. Works well for classic British pale ales, bitters, and stouts.
yeasts.bestFor: English Ales, Bitters, IPAs, Brown Ale

yeasts.name: London Ale
yeasts.notes: Dry, malty ale yeast.  Produces a complex, oak flavored ester character.  Hop bitterness comes through well.
yeasts.bestFor: Classic British Pale Ales, Bitters and Stouts

yeasts.name: London Ale III
yeasts.notes: Light, fruity flavor.  Balanced flavor with hint of sweetness.
yeasts.bestFor: British Ales, Bitters

yeasts.name: London Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Dry finish, bold, rich flavor, some fruit profile and a crisp finish.
yeasts.bestFor: English Ales, Bitters, IPAs, Brown Ale

yeasts.name: London ESB Ale
yeasts.notes: Malty, balanced flavor.  Fruity, rich finish.  Excellent for cask conditioned ales and bitters.
yeasts.bestFor: English Bitters, IPA, Brown Ales, Mild Ales

yeasts.name: Malolactic Bacteria
yeasts.notes: Bacteria for use in secondary.  Malolactic fermentation is the conversion of malic acid to lactic acid by bacteria from the lactic acid bacteria family.  Lactic acid is less acidic than malic acid, which in turn decreases acidity and helps to soften and/o
yeasts.bestFor: Primarily wine

yeasts.name: Manchester
yeasts.notes: Old english style ale yeast that produces a complex, woody, full bodied ale at warm temperature.  Medium attenuation.  Good dry yeast for many english styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Complex, full bodied Porters, Stouts, Ales.

yeasts.name: Manchester Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: Top fermenting strain that is good for top-cropping.  Moderately flocculent with a clean, dry finish.  Low ester profile for producing a balanced English ale.
yeasts.bestFor: English style ales

yeasts.name: Mead
yeasts.notes: A high ester-producing strain conferring fresh, floral esters, especially when fermented cool. This yeast has high alcohol tolerance and ferments well over a wide temperature range.
yeasts.bestFor: Suitable for all styles of mead.

yeasts.name: Merlot Red Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes: Neutral, low fusel alcohol production. Will ferment to dryness, alcohol tolerance to 18%. Vigorous fermenter. WLP740 is well suited for Merlot, Shiraz, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Cabernet, Sauvignon Blanc, and Semillon.  Alcohol Tolerance: 18%
yeasts.bestFor: Merlot, Shiraz, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Cabernet, Sauvignon Blanc, and Semillon

yeasts.name: Mexican Lager
yeasts.notes: Produces clean lager beer, with a crisp finish. Good for Mexican style light lagers, as well as dark lagers. A versatile lager strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Mexican style light and dark lagers.

yeasts.name: Mexican Lager
yeasts.notes: From Mexico City - produces a clean lager beer with a crisp finish.  Good for mexican style beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Mexican style light and dark lagers.

yeasts.name: Midwestern Ale
yeasts.notes:
Midwestern Ale yeast is a single strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae isolated from a storied brewery in the heartland of America, well suited for fermentation of a broad spectrum of worts.

A relatively fast fermenter with good attenuation and pleasant ester profile that can be tuned via the fermentation temperature, this yeast is great for any porter, stout, brown, amber, IPA, pale ale, or American wheat beer.

Expect this yeast to ferment cleaner with a low ester profile at the cooler fermentation temperatures, and produce a more pronounced ester profile at warmer fermentation temperatures
yeasts.bestFor: Porter, stout, brown, amber, IPA, pale ale, or American wheat beer

yeasts.name: Munich Festbier
yeasts.notes: From one of the oldest breweries in Munich, this pure strain is recommended for many German lagers such as Helles, Dunkel, and Oktoberfest. Suggested fermentation temperature: 46-54F; medium attenuation.
yeasts.bestFor: Helles, Dunkel, Oktoberfest

yeasts.name: Munich Lager
yeasts.notes: Unique Pilsner strain.  Very smooth, well-rounded and full bodied.  Benefits from a diacetyl rest.
yeasts.bestFor: Pilsners, Light Lagers, Dortmond/Export, Marzen/Oktoberfest, Dunkel

yeasts.name: Munton Fison Ale
yeasts.notes: Quick starting dry yeast.  Produces some fuity esters.  High attenuation produces clean finish.
yeasts.bestFor: High attenuation yeast good for most ales.

yeasts.name: Munton Fison Premium
yeasts.notes: This yeast produces relatively high ester formation with a low residual sweetness but is also very robust.
yeasts.bestFor: English ale

yeasts.name: Munuch
yeasts.notes: Danstar Munich Wheat Beer yeast originated in Bavaria, Germany, the home of many of the world’s great wheat beer breweries.
yeasts.bestFor: Wheat beers

yeasts.name: New Jersey Ale
yeasts.notes: A flocculent top fermenting ale yeast from a defunct East Coast brewery. It produces a very clean ale.
yeasts.bestFor: American Ales

yeasts.name: New World Strong Ale
yeasts.notes: A top-fermenting ale strain suitable for many types of ales of all strengths. Ferments with a neutral yeast aroma to ensure the full character of the malts and hops are prominent in each beer.
yeasts.bestFor: IPA's, Porters, Russian Imperial Stouts.

yeasts.name: NorCal Ale Five
yeasts.notes: More flocculent and less attenuative than GY001.  Ferments more slowly and leaves a clear beer with residual sweetness and a slight fruity nose.  Excellent for full bodied, malt forward beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Brown, Porter, Amber, Pale, Stout

yeasts.name: NorCal Ale One
yeasts.notes: Clean Fermenting, versatile strain from one of the most famous California Pale Ales.  Neutral flavor profile creates a crisp beer and allows hops to shine.  Strong attenuator and good flocculation perfectly suited for a large variety of styles.  Good choice for high gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Barley wine, Pale ale, Bitter, Scotch ale, IPA, Stout

yeasts.name: North American Lager
yeasts.notes: American and Canadian lager yeast. Malty finish makes it suitable for Marzens/Oktoberfest as well.
yeasts.bestFor: American Pilsner, California Common, Canadian Lager, Oktoberfest, Marzen

yeasts.name: Northeastern Abbey
yeasts.notes:
This yeast was isolated from a beer crafted by a well-known producer of Belgian-style ales in the Northeastern United States. This yeast produces a very mild spiciness and earthy flavor and aroma which is complemented by a subtle but magnificent array of fruity esters, including pear and light citrus fruit.

The brewery from which this strain was isolated uses it in a very versatile manner across an array of Belgian styles. We prefer using this yeast for any and all light Belgian beers, including Wit, Belgian Pale and Belgian Blond, in addition to any experimental fruit beers in which a more unique and robust flavor and aroma profile is desired. Expect this yeast to produce a large, thick krausen.
yeasts.bestFor: Wit, Belgian ale

yeasts.name: Northern German Lager
yeasts.notes: Clean, crisp, traditional lager character.  Strong fermenting and forgiving yeast.  Excellent general purpose lager yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: German pilsners, Mexican and Canadian Lagers

yeasts.name: Northwest Ale
yeasts.notes: Classic Northwest US ale yeast.  Slight fruit flavor, malty ale with good body and balance.
yeasts.bestFor: Oregon Ales, All American Ale styles

yeasts.name: Noth-Eastern Micro Ale
yeasts.notes: Malty, bready, yet clean malt character.  Leaves hops flavor and aroma intact.  Versitile yeast for many American styles.
yeasts.bestFor: American Ales, Reds, Ambers

yeasts.name: Nottingham
yeasts.notes: Dry strain is highly flocculant and has high attenuation.  Produces relatively few fruity esters for a dry yeast. Can be fermented at low temperature to produce lager-style beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Good neutral ale yeast.

yeasts.name: Nottingham Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: British style of ale yeast with a very dry finish and high attenuation.  Medium to low fruit and fusel alcohol production.  Good top fermenting yeast for cropping.
yeasts.bestFor: British ales, pale ales, ambers, porters and stouts.

yeasts.name: Nottingham Yeast
yeasts.notes: High flocculation - settles quickly.  Very good reputation as a fast starter and quick fermenter.  Clean and only slightly fruity.  Some nutty flavor in bottled version.  Relatively high attenuation.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales

yeasts.name: Octoberfest Lager Blend
yeasts.notes: This blend of lager strains is designed to produce a rich, malty, complex and full bodied Octoberfest style beer. It attenuates well while leaving plenty of malt character and mouthfeel. This strain is low in sulfur production.
yeasts.bestFor: Octoberfest, Marzen, Bavarian lagers

yeasts.name: Octoberfest/Marzen Lager
yeasts.notes: Produces a malty, bock style beer.  Does not finish as dry or as fast as White's German Lager yeast.  Longer lagering or starter recommended.
yeasts.bestFor: Marzen, Oktoberfest, European Lagers, Bocks, Munich Helles

yeasts.name: Oktoberfest
yeasts.notes: Produces rich, full-bodied, malty beers. This strain is a good choice for bocks and doppelbocks. A thorough diacetyl rest is recommended after fermentation is complete.
yeasts.bestFor: Marzen, Oktoberfest, European Lagers, Bocks, Munich Helles

yeasts.name: Old Bavarian Lager
yeasts.notes: Well rounded, malty with a subtle ester complex and citrus flavors.  Distinct, flavorful yeast is great for Southern German lager styles.
yeasts.bestFor: German lagers, Bock, Dunkel, Helles

yeasts.name: Old Bavarian Lager
yeasts.notes: Southern Germany/Bavarian lager yeast.  Finishes malty with a slight ester profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bock and Dark Lagers.

yeasts.name: Old German Ale
yeasts.notes: Traditional Alt Bier flavor.  Strong fermenter with a smooth, attenuated, mild flavor.  Slightly dry, clean, quenching finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Altbier, German ales, some Wheat beers.

yeasts.name: Ols Newark Ale
yeasts.notes: Sourced from a defunct east coast brewery, this pure strain was identified as their "ale-pitching yeast". Good for all styles of American and English ales with high flocculation and a compact sedimentation. Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-68F; attenuation ~76%.
yeasts.bestFor: American ales, English ales

yeasts.name: Original Pilsner
yeasts.notes: Full bodied lager yeast with sweet, underattenuated finish.  Subdued diacetyl character.  Big malty palatte.  Classic Pilsner finish and style.
yeasts.bestFor: Classic Czech Pilsners

yeasts.name: Oud Brune
yeasts.notes: For primary fermentations. A unique blend of fruity Belgian Saccharomyces yeast and Lactobacilli species (L. delbrueckii and L. brevis). For those who prefer sourness without the presence of Brett. Additional info: Suggested fermentation temperature: 68-74ºF
yeasts.bestFor: Sours

yeasts.name: Pacific Ale
yeasts.notes: Popular yeast from the Pacific Northwest.  Leaves a clear and malty profile.  More fruity than WLP002.  Suitable for many English and American styles.
yeasts.bestFor: English & American ales including milds, bitters, IPA, porters and English stouts.

yeasts.name: Pacific NW Ale
yeasts.notes: Produces a malty and mildly fruity ale with good depth and complexity.
yeasts.bestFor: English & American ales including milds, bitters, IPA, porters and English stouts.

yeasts.name: Pasteur Champagne
yeasts.notes: High attenuation dry yeast. Good reputation.  Good for Meads and other high gravity ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Meads, Barleywines, Imperial Stouts and high gravity ales.

yeasts.name: Pediococcus
yeasts.notes: Lactic acid bacteria used in the production of Belgian style beers where additional acidity is desirable. Often found in gueuze and other Belgian style beer. Acid production will increase with storage time. It may also cause ropiness and produce low level
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour ales

yeasts.name: Pediococcus Cerevisiae
yeasts.notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium.  Creates a high level of lactic acidity over a long time.  Often used with other yeasts, and it may take several months for flavor to fully develop.
yeasts.bestFor: Gueze and other Belgian styles.

yeasts.name: Pediococcus Damnosus
yeasts.notes: Slow growing bacteria used in secondary to create lactic acid flavor in Belgian lambics.  Produces large amounts of lactic acid and diacytl.  Prefers anaerobic conditions.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic beers

yeasts.name: Pediococcus Damnosus
yeasts.notes: Pediococcus damnosus is a cocci bacteria known for its souring capabilities by producing lactic acid. Perfect to add to any sour program. High diacetyl producer and slow growing.
yeasts.bestFor: Sours

yeasts.name: Pilsen Lager
yeasts.notes: Classic American pilsner strain.  Smooth with a malty flavor.  Dry and crisp fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: American Pilsner, Bohemian Pilsner, Light Lagers

yeasts.name: Pilsner I
yeasts.notes: Classic pilsner strain from a pilsner producer in the Czech Republic. Somewhat dry with a malty finish, this yeast is best suited for European pilsner production.
yeasts.bestFor: European Pilsners, Bohemian Pilsner

yeasts.name: Pilsner II
yeasts.notes: From the Czech Republic, this strain will finish dry and malty. The perfect choice for Bohemian-style pilsners. Sulfur produced during fermentation can be reduced with warmer fermentation temperatures (58F) and will dissipate with conditioning.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian and American Pilsner, Bocks, Oktoberfest, Marzen

yeasts.name: Pilsner Lager
yeasts.notes: Classic pilsner strain from Czech Republic.  Dry with a malty finish.
yeasts.bestFor: European Pilsners, Bohemian Pilsner

yeasts.name: Portland Hefe
yeasts.notes: Used to make a famous American Wheat Beer. Creates a clean tasting crisp brew with just a hint of banana and spice.  Very low flocculation means a hazy beer true to the hefe style.
yeasts.bestFor: America Wheat Beer, Weizenbock, Dunkelweizen, Hefeweizen

yeasts.name: Premium Bitter Ale
yeasts.notes: From Staffordshire England.  Mild, but complex estery flavor.  High attenuation - ferments strong and dry.  Suitable for high gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: All English ales including bitters, milds, ESB, Porter, Stout and Barley Wine

yeasts.name: Quebec Abbey
yeasts.notes: From one of the first breweries in North America to create a successful line of traditional Abbey style ales.  This Belgian ale yeast creates a malt forward beer with subtle fruity esters and a very small amount of clove notes.   Robust attenuation makes this yeast an excellent choice for low or high gravity beers where a slightly sweet malty finish is desired.  Perfect for the Belgian Dubbel and Tripel styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Red Star Ale
yeasts.notes: Good general purpose dry yeast. Change to a different strain in recent years has improved overall quality.
yeasts.bestFor: High attenuation ales with a dry clean taste.

yeasts.name: Red Wine
yeasts.bestFor: Ideal for red or white wines, which mature rapidly with Beaujolais type fruitiness, and for bigger reds requiring aging. Low foaming, low sulfur production over a broad range of temperatures.

yeasts.name: Ringwood Ale
yeasts.notes: European ale yeast.  Highly flocculant with complex, clear, but malty profile.  Slightly fruity ester.
yeasts.bestFor: Ringwood Ale, Brown Ales

yeasts.name: Roselare Belgian Blend
yeasts.notes: Culture of Saccharomyces, Brettonomyces and Lactic Acid Bacteria.  Complex aromas and flavors.  May be used for primary fermentation.  Primarily for sour brown and red Belgian styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian sour brown and red beers.

yeasts.name: SafAle English Ale
yeasts.notes: Fast starting, fast fermenting yeast.  Quick attenuation helps to produce a clean, crisp, clear ale.  Can be used in a wide range of ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Great general purpose ale yeast.

yeasts.name: SafAle German Ale
yeasts.notes: Low sedimentation yeast, sometimes used in open fermentation. Good for wheat beers, weizens and light ales.
yeasts.bestFor: High attenuation ales, wheat beers and weizens.

yeasts.name: SafBrew Abbaye
yeasts.notes:
Levure sèche active adaptée au brassage de bières caractérisées par de fortes teneurs en alcool, dont celles de type Abbaye. Elle fermente
très rapidement et révèle des arômes subtils et équilibrés.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale

yeasts.name: SafBrew Ale
yeasts.notes: General purpose ale yeast, widely used.  Very consistent, clean finish. High attenuation and good flavor profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Most ales.

yeasts.name: SafBrew Specialty Ale
yeasts.notes: Estery, somewhat spicy ale yeast. Solid yeast formation at end of fermentation.  Widely used for bottle and cask conditioning.
yeasts.bestFor: Complex ales.

yeasts.name: SafLager German Lager
yeasts.notes: Popular lager yeast strain.  Produces wide range of continental lagers and pilsners.  Clean finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Wide range of lagers and pilsners.

yeasts.name: SafLager West European Lager
yeasts.notes: German lager yeast strain.  Performs well at low temperature. High flocculation and attenuation for a clean German finish.
yeasts.bestFor: German style Lagers and Pilsners.

yeasts.name: Safale American
yeasts.notes: American ale yeast that produces well balanced beers with low diacetyl and a very clean, crisp end palate.
yeasts.bestFor: American ale, other clean finish ales

yeasts.name: Safbrew Wheat
yeasts.notes: A specialty yeast for wheat beer fermentation.  The yeast produces a subtle estery and phenlol flavor typical of wheat beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Wheat beers

yeasts.name: Safebrew Abbey Ale
yeasts.notes: Active dry yeast recommended to brew a diversity of beers amongst which abbey style beers known for their high alcohol content. It ferments very fast and reveals subtle and well-balanced aromas. To maintain the aromatic profile at the end of the fermentation crop the yeast as soon as possible after fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: Abbey Ales

yeasts.name: Saflager Lager
yeasts.notes: A famous yeast strain from Weihenstephan Germany used worldwide in brewing.  Their most popular strain for lagers.
yeasts.bestFor: European lagers

yeasts.name: Saison
yeasts.notes: Pleasant yeast blend.  Leaves a smooth full character to the malt with mild, but pleasant esters and some apple pie spices.
yeasts.bestFor: French or Belgian Ales and Grand Cru styles.

yeasts.name: Saison Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend of Saison yeast. This Blend is a super robust attenuator that produces a complex flavor profile of fruit and spice.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Saison Blend
yeasts.notes: A blend of two unique yeast strains isolated from beers that embody the saison style, this blend is a balance of the many characteristic saison flavors and aromas. One yeast strain is a good attenuator that produces a spicy and mildly tart and tangy beer with a full mouthfeel. The other yeast strain is also a good attenuator that produces a delightful ester profile of grapefruit and orange zest and imparts a long, dry and earthy finish to the beer. Together, they produce a dry but balanced beer with a unique flavor and aroma profile.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison

yeasts.name: Saison Blend II
yeasts.notes:
This saison blend is the Saccharomyces portion of our Farmhouse Sour Ale, available to you as a result of popular demand from the commercial brewing crowd. This combination of Saccharomyces strains embodies the balanced fusion of the two foremost saison flavor/aroma characters, fruitiness and earthiness.

Each Saccharomyces strain in this blend produces flavor compounds that serve as the yin to the other's yang, and the result is an exceptionally complex yet balanced flavor and aroma profile. One strain will serve to create an ester profile of grapefruit and orange zest, while the other will produce a mild earthiness and spiciness.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse ale

yeasts.name: Saison Brasserie
yeasts.notes: A combination of several saison yeast strains for both fruity and spicy characteristics accompanied with dryness (attenuation ~ 80%). Suggested fermentation temperature: 75-85F.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Saison Single
yeasts.notes: This strain leaves a smooth, full farmhouse character with mild esters reminiscent of apple pie spice. Attenuation 76-78%; fermentation temperature: 75-82F.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Saison Sour
yeasts.notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze

yeasts.name: Saison Yeast One
yeasts.notes: Traditional Saison yeast from a French craft brewery.  Produces fragrant beer with pepper and fruit notes.  Warmer fermentations create more intense flavors.   Perfect for accentuating citrus and fruit flavors.  High attenuation rates make a dryer beer than Saison #2
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Saison Yeast Two
yeasts.notes: From a traditional farmhouse Saison. Creates the fruity/spicy aroma traditional to the style.  Warmer fermentation temps result in more intense flavor.  Produces a tartness not found in most of our yeast and a slightly sweeter beer than GY018 (Saison #1).
yeasts.bestFor: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde

yeasts.name: Saisonstein’s Monster
yeasts.notes: The first in our line of hybrid strains. This strain is a genetic hybrid resulting from the mating of strains OYL-026 and OYL-027, created by and available exclusively from Omega Yeast. Less phenolic and more fruit character than 026. Exhibits some of the bubble gum character of 027.

yeasts.name: Sake Yeast
yeasts.notes: For use in rice based fermentations. For sake, use this yeast in conjunction with Koji (to produce fermentable sugar). WLP705 produces full body sake character, and subtle fragrance.  Alcohol tolerance to 16%.
yeasts.bestFor: Sake wine yeast

yeasts.name: San Diego Super Yeast
yeasts.notes: A super clean, super-fast fermenting strain. A low ester-producing strain that results in a balanced, neutral flavor and aroma profile. Alcohol-tolerant and very versatile for a wide variety of styles. Similar to California Ale Yeast WLP001 but it generally ferments faster.
yeasts.bestFor: American Style Ales, Ambers, Pale Ales, Brown Ale, Strong Ale

yeasts.name: San Francisco Lager
yeasts.notes: Produces "California Common" style beer.
yeasts.bestFor: California and Premium Lagers, all American Lagers

yeasts.name: Scotch Ale One
yeasts.notes: This is one sweet yeast.  Neutral flavors emphasize the malt.  Leaves a slight residual sweetness and body in high gravity beers perfect for malt forward styles like scotch ales, wee heavy, stouts and porters.
yeasts.bestFor: Scotch Ale, Pale Ale, Wee Heavy, Brown Ale, Porter, Stout

yeasts.name: Scottish Ale
yeasts.notes: Use for classic Scottish heavys, 90's- or strong ales. This yeast produces a soft, fruity malt profile with a subtle woody, oakey ester profile. A mild, mineral like dryness in the finish makes this a very complex strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Scottish ales

yeasts.name: Scottish Ale
yeasts.notes: Produces complex, flavorful Scottish style ales. Often used as a “house” strain. Hop character is not muted with this strain.
yeasts.bestFor: Scottish Ale, Scottish Strong Ales, Sweet Stout, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

yeasts.name: Scottish Ale
yeasts.notes: High alcohol tolerance.
yeasts.bestFor: Scottish Ale, Scottish Strong Ales, Sweet Stout, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

yeasts.name: Scottish Bitter
yeasts.notes: CL-210 has a soft, yeasty, fruity nose which yields to a well attenuated malt flavor and big ester complex of ripe fruit, apricots and rose petals. Dry and complex, yet smooth and fruity with mild sulphur.
yeasts.bestFor: Scottish Ales

yeasts.name: Scottish Heavy
yeasts.notes: Leaves a fruity profile with woody, oak esters reminiscent of malt whiskey. Well suited for 90/ shilling or heavier ales including old ales and barleywines due to the level of attenuation (77-80%). Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-68F.
yeasts.bestFor: Heavy Ales, 90/ Shilling, Barley wine

yeasts.name: Scourmont Abbey
yeasts.notes: Classic Belgian yeast from one of the best known Trappist breweries.  A fragrant yeast that produces delicious fruity aroma.  Good choice for high gravity beers.  Generally, the warmer this yeast is fermented the higher the level of fruit aromas produced.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Beire de Garde, Saison

yeasts.name: Sour Cherry Funk
yeasts.notes: This blend creates an amazing complex, sour beer with fruity cherry esters.  Fermenting in the presence of 7-10 IBUs will cause the fermentation to complete much more quickly but will slow the souring —  expect to wait 3-4 months for significant souring.  Fermenting with zero or less than 5 IBUs will allow souring to happen much faster (within two weeks) but will cause the fermentation to take up to 4 weeks to complete.
yeasts.bestFor: Sours

yeasts.name: Sour Plum Belgian
yeasts.notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.
yeasts.bestFor: Trapist Ales, Sours

yeasts.name: Southern German Lager
yeasts.notes: Malty finish and balanced aroma.  Strong fermenter, slight sulfur and low diacetyl.
yeasts.bestFor: German Pilsner, Helles, Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bocks

yeasts.name: Southwold Ale
yeasts.notes: From Suffolk county.  Products complex fruity and citrus flavors.  Slight sulfer production, but this will fade with ageing.
yeasts.bestFor: British bitters and pale ales.

yeasts.name: Special Ale
yeasts.notes: Highly attentive, clean finish dry yeast.
yeasts.bestFor: All-malt beers.

yeasts.name: Steinberg-Geisenheim Wine
yeasts.notes: German origin wine yeast.  High fruit/ester production.  Moderate fermentation characteristics and cold tolerant.
yeasts.bestFor: Riesling wines.

yeasts.name: Summation Red
yeasts.notes: Produces distinctive intense berry, graham cracker nose. Jammy, rich, very smooth complex profile, slightly vinous. Well suited to higher sugar content musts.
yeasts.bestFor: Cabernet, Malbec, Port, Sauvignon Blanc, Merlot

yeasts.name: Super High Gravity Ale
yeasts.notes: Ferments up to 25% alcohol content.  Flavor may vary greatly depending on beer alcohol.  English like esters at low gravity, but will become more wine-like as alcohol exceeds 16% ABV.  Refer to White Labs web page for tips on fermenting high gravity ales.
yeasts.bestFor: Very high gravity beers and barley wine up to 25% alcohol.

yeasts.name: Suremain Burgundy Wine Yeast
yeasts.notes:
Emphasizes fruit aromas in barrel fermentations. High nutrient requirement to avoid volatile acidity production. 
Alcohol Tolerance: 16%
yeasts.bestFor: Burgundy

yeasts.name: Sweet Flemish Brettt
yeasts.notes: Brew with GB144 on it’s own to make an all brett beer, in a primary fermentation with an ale yeast for a complex blended profile or in a secondary to add character during aging.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Sweet Mead
yeasts.notes: Leaves 2-3% residual sugar in most meads. Rich, fruity profile complements fruit mead fermentations. Use of Vintner's Choice yeast nutrient is recommended.
yeasts.bestFor: Common cider, sweet mead, Braggot

yeasts.name: Sweet Mead/Wine
yeasts.notes: Lower attenuation than White Labs Champagne Yeast.  Leaves some residual sweetness as well as fruity flavor.  Alcohol concentration up to 15%.
yeasts.bestFor: Sweet Mead, Wine and Cider

yeasts.name: Sweet White
yeasts.notes: Produces distinct Riesling character. Rich flavor, creamy, fruity profile with nice dry finish and a hint of Riesling sweetness in the aftertaste.
yeasts.bestFor: Braggot, Cider, Dry Mead, Icewine, Fruit cider, Sweet mead, Vermouth

yeasts.name: Swiss Lager
yeasts.notes: A unique strain that has both a clean, crisp lager flavor and a soft, smooth maltiness. Perfect for European Pilsners. Like our CL-660 strain, this is an excellent all purpose Lager yeast for those wanting a fuller, rounder palate.
yeasts.bestFor: European pilsners and lagers

yeasts.name: Swiss Lager
yeasts.notes: This yeast can be used to produce lager beer over 11% ABV. Sulfur and diacetyl production is minimal.
yeasts.bestFor: Swiss style lager, and high gravity lagers (over 11% ABV)

yeasts.name: Tart Cherry Brett
yeasts.notes:
Produces some Brett Barnyard funk plus stone fruit and cherry-like esters.  This Strain also produces a moderate amount of acid that adds a tart complexity to the brew.

This yeast is highly attenuative but tends to ferment about ½ as fast as a typical ale strain.  Although it attenuates faster than GB001, it is typically best used in combination with faster fermenting yeast in the primary or added to the secondary to add complexity while aging.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns

yeasts.name: Thames Valley Ale
yeasts.notes: Clean, complex flavor.  Low in fruit, low in esters, rich in flavor.  Hops come through well.
yeasts.bestFor: British Bitters, ESB, India Pale Ale, English Strong Ale

yeasts.name: Top
yeasts.notes:
Top fermenting yeast that most suitable for amber coloured and dark beers. Fast
fermentation with low residual sugar. Formation of fruity esters.
yeasts.bestFor: American IPA, Dark ales, Witbier

yeasts.name: Trappist Ale
yeasts.notes: Distinctive fruitiness and plum characteristics.  Excellent for high gravity beers.
yeasts.bestFor: Trappist Ale, Dubbel, Trippel, Belgian Ales

yeasts.name: Trappist High Gravity
yeasts.notes: Robust top cropping yeast.  Phenolic character and alcohol tolerance up to 12%.  Rich ester profile and malty flavor.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit, Trappist Ale, High gravity ales

yeasts.name: Trappist Tripel
yeasts.notes: Trappist Ale yeast from the mother of all Tripels.  A balance of fruit and spice with a  good malty finish provides a perfect complement for Belgian Ales, Dubbels and Tripels.   Attenuation is on the slow side leaving more residual sweetness than our other Belgians. Less esters and phenolics than GY003 and GY014.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde, Saison

yeasts.name: Tropical IPA
yeasts.notes: A unique strain formerly classified as Brettanomyces but since found to be Saccharomyces.  Produces a beer with tropical fruit characteristics of mango and pineapple. Can also be used to produce effervescence when bottle-conditioning.
yeasts.bestFor: Sour beers, Belgian Sour Variations

yeasts.name: UK Dark Ale
yeasts.notes: A top fermenting ale yeast suitable for a variety of hearty British ales, promoting exceptional body and flavour. Ferments with full, rich dark fruit flavours.
yeasts.bestFor: Dark mild ale, English brown ale, Scottish heavy ale.

yeasts.name: US West Coast
yeasts.notes: A top fermenting ale strain suitable for American style ales. This yeast produces an exceptionally clean flavour, ideal for when you want the hop character to really punch through.
yeasts.bestFor: American style pale ale, American double IPA, American style imperial stout and more

yeasts.name: Urquell Lager
yeasts.notes: Pilsner Urquell yeast with mild fruit/floral aroma.  Very dry and clean on palate with full mouth feel.  Subtle malt character.  Clean and neutral finish.
yeasts.bestFor: Bohemian Pilsner

yeasts.name: Vermont Ale
yeasts.notes:
Isolated from a uniquely crafted double IPA out of the Northeastern United States, this yeast produces a balanced fruity ester profile of peaches and light citrus that complements any aggressively hopped beer. Expect this strain to take off fast and ferment wort quickly, though elevating the temperature following the bulk of fermentation may be required to raise the attenuation.

In order to achieve high attenuation, we recommend fermenting at 64-68 ºF for 5-7 days, and then raising the temperature to 70 ºF until a stable gravity is reached. We also recommend mashing at 148-149 ºF and adding a small percentage of the fermentables (~ 5-10%) as sugar.
yeasts.bestFor: IPA

yeasts.name: Vermont IPA
yeasts.notes: From one of the best examples of an east coast IPA.  This yeast attenuates slightly less than NorCal Ale #1 and leaves a beer with more body and a slight fruity ester that is amazing with aromatic hops.  Good choice for high gravity beers and hoppy styles.  Broad temperature range and moderate flocculation make this yeast a versatile house strain.
yeasts.bestFor: IPA, American Wheat, Pale Ale, Bitter, West Coast Amber, ESB

yeasts.name: Voss Kveik
yeasts.notes: A traditional Norwegian “kveik” strain from the farmhouse brewery of Sigmund Gjernes in Voss, Norway, this strain (like OYL-057 HotHead) is capable of fermenting across a broad temperature range with little change in flavor profile.  Voss Kveik is non-phenolic and produces a beer with moderate citrus notes.  It would pair very well with citrusy and fruity hops.  This strain is not fast at the low end of the range so don’t be afraid to pitch in the middle to upper part of the temperature range.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales

yeasts.name: Wallonian Farmhouse
yeasts.notes:
Isolated from a unique farmhouse-style ale that hails from the Walloon region of Belgium, this yeast is one of the funkiest "clean" yeast we have in our stable. It imparts a slight earthy funk and tart character to the beer, and is a very mild producer of some slightly spicy and mildly smokey flavor compounds.

This yeast exhibits absurdly high attenuation, resulting in a practically bone-dry beer. If desired, we recommend controlling the dryness by adjusting the mash temperature or adding malts or adjuncts to the mash tun that will lend some body and residual sweetness to the beer.

When fermented cool this yeast will provide a cleaner profile, and the character development will increase proportionally with increasing fermentation temperature.
yeasts.bestFor: Farmhouse ale, Belgian ale

yeasts.name: Weihenstephan Weizen
yeasts.notes: Unique Bavarian wheat yeast that produces the spicy weizen clove and banana flavor.  Best when fermented at around 68 deg F.
yeasts.bestFor: Bavarian Weizen

yeasts.name: West Coast Ale I
yeasts.notes: Clean, crisp flavor characteristics with low fruitiness and mild ester production. A very versatile yeast for styles that desire dominant malt and hop character. A very popular “house” strain. May yield citrus notes with cooler 60-66°F fermentations.
yeasts.bestFor: American Style Ales, Ambers, Pale Ales, Brown Ale, Strong Ale

yeasts.name: West Coast II
yeasts.notes: A versatile strain and a good choice for a “House” strain. Provides a soft, clean profile with hints of nut, and a slightly tart finish. Ferment at warmer temperatures to accentuate hop character with an increased fruitiness. Or, ferment cool for a clean, light citrus character. It attenuates well and is reliably flocculent, producing bright beer without filtration.
yeasts.bestFor: American style Pales, Ambers, Browns, IPAs, American Strong Ale

yeasts.name: West Coast III
yeasts.notes: A clean, fast fermenting strain similar to West Coast Ale I. A low ester-producing strain that results in a balanced, neutral flavor and aroma profile. Alcohol-tolerant and very versatile for a wide variety of styles.
yeasts.bestFor: A wide variety of styles requiring clean, fast fermentation and finish.

yeasts.name: West Coast IPA
yeasts.notes: Thorough attenuation, temp tolerance, and good flocculation make this an easy strain to work with. Flavor is balanced neutral with mild ester formation at warmer temps, allowing hops, character malts, and flavorings to show through.
yeasts.bestFor: American IPA, Imperial IPA, American Pale Ale, American brown ale, Red Ales, Scottish Ales

yeasts.name: West Coast IV
yeasts.notes: Excellent attenuation, temperature tolerance, and good flocculation make this an easy strain to work with. Flavor is balanced neutral with mild ester formation at warmer temps, allowing hops, character malts, and flavorings to show through.
yeasts.bestFor: West-coast style American craft beers, especially pale, IPA, red, and specialties

yeasts.name: West Coast Lager
yeasts.notes: Produces California Common-style beers. Retains lager characteristics at temperatures up to 65°F and produces malty, brilliantly clear beers. This strain is not recommended for cold temperature fermentation.
yeasts.bestFor: California and Premium Lagers, all American Lagers

yeasts.name: Westmalle Blonde
yeasts.notes: Récupérée depuis un fond de bouteille, il est fortement recommandé au minimum de faire un starter ou deux une semaine à l'avance pour avoir un pied de cuve digne de ce nom
yeasts.bestFor: Triple Trappiste clône de Westmalle

yeasts.name: Where Da Funk?
yeasts.notes: A blend of a mild Brettanomyces isolate from a Colorado brewery known for its Brett beers and two strains formerly classified as Brettanomyces but since found to be Saccharomyces. This blend produces huge tropical fruit aromas during fermentation that fade somewhat during conditioning. Has a wide temperature range and ferments very dry, leaving little body. Consider adding flaked oats if additional body is desired. This blend will not produce significant “funk” or acid, even with extended aging. The blend pairs well with fruity aroma hops to make a unique pale ale.
yeasts.bestFor: Lambic

yeasts.name: Whitbread Ale
yeasts.notes: Slightly more fruity and malty than Wyeast's British Ale.  Clear and highly flocculant.
yeasts.bestFor: Whitbread Ale, British Ales, Pales, Bitters

yeasts.name: Windsor Yeast
yeasts.notes: Clean, well balanced finish.  Yeast produces an estery ale with a slighly fresh yeast flavor.  Not as quick as the Nottingham.  Some bannana aroma.
yeasts.bestFor: Ales

yeasts.name: Wit
yeasts.notes: Produces a complex flavor profile dominated by spicy phenolics with low to moderate ester production. It is a great strain choice when you want a delicate clove profile not to be overshadowed by esters. It will ferment fairly dry with a slightly tart finish that compliments the use of oats, malted and unmalted wheat. This strain is a true top cropping yeast requiring full fermenter headspace of 33%.
yeasts.bestFor: Belgian Wit

yeasts.name: Wyeast Ale Blend
yeasts.notes: Blend of ale strains designed to provide quick starts, good flavor, balance and flocculation.  Balanced finish suitable for most American and British ale styles.
yeasts.bestFor: American and British Ale Styles.

yeasts.name: Wyeast Lager Blend
yeasts.notes: Blend of lager strains to produce a complex but clean lager flavor profile.  Suitable for many common lager styles.
yeasts.bestFor: Classic Pilsners, Lagers, Bocks.

yeasts.name: Yorkshire Square Ale Yeast
yeasts.notes: This yeast produces a malty but well balanced profile.  Expect toasty flavors with malt driven esters.  Highly flocculent and a good choice for many English ales.
yeasts.bestFor: English pale ales, English brown ales and Mild ales

yeasts.name: Zurich Lager
yeasts.notes: Swiss style lager yeast.  Sulfer and diacytl production is minimal.  May be used for high gravity lagers with proper care.
yeasts.bestFor: Swiss style lager, and high gravity lagers (over 11% ABV)
